div.head: SCENE I
div.stage: SCENE : A street in Peking

Several shops are shown . Their fronts are richly decorated with carved wood painted red and profusely gilt . The counters are elaborately carved . Outside are huge sign-boards . The shops are open to the street and you can see the various wares they sell . One is a coffin shop , where the coolies are at work on a coffin : other coffins , ready for sale , are displayed ; some of them are of plain deal , others are rich , with black and gold . The next shop is a money changer 's . Then there is a lantern shop in which all manner of coloured lanterns are hanging . After this comes a druggist where there are queer things in bottles and dried herbs . A small stuffed crocodile is a prominent object . Next to this is a shop where crockery is sold , large coloured jars , plates , and all manner of strange animals . In all the shops two or three Chinamen are seated . Some read newspapers through great horn spectacles ; some smoke water pipes .

The street is crowded . Here is an itinerant cook with his two chests , in one of which is burning charcoal : he serves out bowls of rice and condiments to the passers-by who want food . There is a barber with the utensils of his trade . A coolie , seated on a stool , is having his head shaved . Chinese walk to and fro .

Some are coolies and wear blue cotton in various stages of raggedness ; some in black gowns and caps and black shoes are merchants and clerks . There is a beggar , gaunt and thin , with an untidy mop of bristly hair , in tatters of indescribable filthiness . He stops at one of the shops and begins a long wail . For a time no one takes any notice of him , but presently on a word from the fat shopkeeper an assistant gives him a few cash and he wanders on . Coolies , half naked , hurry by , bearing great bales on their yokes . They utter little sharp cries for people to get out of their way . Peking carts with their blue hoods rumble noisily along . Rickshaws pass rapidly in both directions , and the rickshaw boys shout for the crowd to make way . In the rickshaws are grave Chinese . Some are dressed in white ducks after the European fashion ; in other rickshaws are Chinese women in long smocks and wide trousers or Manchu ladies , with their faces painted like masks , in embroidered silks . Women of various sorts stroll about the street or enter the shops . You see them chaffering for various articles .

A water-carrier passes along with a creaking barrow , slopping the water as he goes ; an old blind woman , a masseuse , advances slowly , striking wooden clappers to proclaim her calling . A musician stands on the curb and plays a tuneless melody on a one-stringed fiddle . From the distance comes the muffled sound of gongs . There is a babel of sound caused by the talking of all these people , by the cries of coolies , the gong , the clappers , and the fiddle . From burning joss-sticks in the shops in front of the household god comes a savour of incense .

A couple of Mongols ride across on shaggy ponies ; they wear high boots and Astrakhan caps . Then a string of camels sways slowly down the street . They carry great burdens of skins from the deserts of Mongolia . They are accompanied by wild looking fellows . Two stout Chinese gentlemen are giving their pet birds an airing ; the birds are attached by the leg with a string and sit on little wooden perches . The two Chinese gentlemen discuss their merits . Round about them small boys play . They run hither and thither pursuing one another amid the crowd .

div.head: SCENE II

stage.stage: A small verandah on an upper storey of the British American Tobacco Company 's premises , the upper part of which the staff lives in . At the back are heavy arches of whitewashed masonry and a low wall which serves as a parapet . Green blinds are drawn . There is a bamboo table on which are copies of illustrated papers . A couple of long bamboo chairs and two or three smaller arm chairs . The floor is tiled .

On one of the long chairs HAROLD KNOX is lying asleep . He is a young man of pleasing appearance . He wears white ducks , but he has taken off his coat , which lies on a chair , and his collar and tie and pin . They are on the table by his side . He is troubled by a fly and , half waking but with his eyes still closed , tries to drive it away .

sp.speaker: KNOX
sp.p: Curse it .He opens his eyes and yawns .Boy !

sp.speaker: WU
sp.p: Outside .Ye .

sp.speaker: KNOX
sp.p: What 's the time ?

div.stage: WU comes in ; he is a Chinese servant in a long white gown with a black cap on his head . He bears a tray on which is a bottle of whisky , a glass and a syphon .

sp.speaker: WU
sp.p: My no sabe .

sp.speaker: KNOX
sp.p: Anyhow it 's time for a whisky and soda .WU puts the tray down on the table . KNOX smiles .Intelligent anticipation . Model servant and all that sort of thing .WU pours out the whisky .You do n't care if I drink myself to death , Wu — do you ?WU smiles , showing all his teeth .Fault of the climate . Give me the glass .WU does so .You 're like a mother to me , Wu .He drinks and puts down the glass .By George , I feel another man . The bull-dog breed , Wu . Never say die . Rule Britannia . Pull up the blinds , you lazy blighter . The sun 's off and the place is like a oven .

div.stage: WU goes over and pulls up one blind after the other . An expanse of blue sky is seen . HENRY ANDERSON comes in . He is a man of thirty , fair , good-looking , with a pleasant , honest face . His obvious straightforwardness and sincerity make him attractive .

sp.speaker: HARRY
sp.p: Breezily .Hulloa , Harold , you seem to be taking it easy .

sp.speaker: KNOX
sp.p: There was nothing to do in the office and I thought I 'd get in my beauty sleep while I had the chance .

sp.speaker: HARRY
sp.p: I thought you had your beauty sleep before midnight .

sp.speaker: KNOX
sp.p: I 'm taking time by the forelock so as to be on the safe side .

sp.speaker: HARRY
sp.p: Are you going on the loose again to-night ?

sp.speaker: KNOX
sp.p: Again , Henry ?

sp.speaker: HARRY
sp.p: You were blind last night .

sp.speaker: KNOX
sp.p: With great satisfaction .Paralytic .... Hulloa , who 's this ?He catches sight of the AMAH who has just entered . She is a little , thin , wrinkled , elderly Chinawoman in a long smock and trousers . She has gold pins in her sleek black hair . When she sees she has been noticed she smiles obsequiously .Well , fair charmer , what can we do for you ?

sp.speaker: HARRY
sp.p: What does she want , Wu ?

sp.speaker: KNOX
sp.p: Is this the face that launched a thousand ships ?

sp.speaker: AMAH
sp.p: My Missy have pay my letter .

sp.speaker: HARRY
sp.p: With sudden eager interest .Are you Mrs. Rathbone 's amah ? Have you got a letter for me ?

sp.speaker: AMAH
sp.p: My belong Missy Rathbone amah .

lg.l: Well , hurry up , do n't be all night about it . Lend me a dollar ,
Harold . I want to give it to the old girl .

div.stage: The AMAH takes a note out of her sleeve and gives it to HARRY . He opens it and reads .

sp.speaker: KNOX
sp.p: I have n't got a dollar . Give her a chit or ask Wu . He 's the only man I know who 's got any money .

sp.speaker: HARRY
sp.p: Let me have a dollar , Wu . Chop-chop .

sp.speaker: WU
sp.p: My go catchee .

div.stage: He goes out . The AMAH is standing near the table . While KNOX and HARRY go on talking she notices KNOX 'S pin . She smiles and smiles and makes little bows to the two men , but at the same time her hand cautiously reaches out for the pin and closes on it . Then she secretes it in her sleeve .

sp.speaker: HARRY
sp.p: I thought you were going to play tennis this afternoon .

sp.speaker: KNOX
sp.p: So I am later on .

sp.speaker: HARRY
sp.p: Smiling .Do it now , dear boy . That is a precept a business man should never forget .

sp.speaker: KNOX
sp.p: I should hate to think you wanted to be rid of me .

sp.speaker: HARRY
sp.p: I dote on your company , but I feel that I must n't be selfish .

sp.speaker: KNOX
sp.p: Pulling his leg .To tell you the truth I do n't feel very fit to-day .

sp.speaker: HARRY
sp.p: A little bilious , I dare say . Half a dozen hard sets are just what you want .He hands KNOX his coat .

sp.speaker: KNOX
sp.p: What is this ?

sp.speaker: HARRY
sp.p: Your coat .

sp.speaker: KNOX
sp.p: You 're making yourself almost more distressingly plain than nature has already made you .

div.stage: WU comes back and hands HARRY a dollar , and then goes out . HARRY gives the dollar to the AMAH .

sp.speaker: HARRY
sp.p: Here 's a dollar for you , amah . You go back to missy and tell her it 's all right and will she come chop-chop . Sabe ?

sp.speaker: AMAH
sp.p: My sabe . Goo ’ - bye .

sp.speaker: KNOX
sp.p: God bless you , dearie . It 's done me good to see your winsome little face .

sp.speaker: HARRY
sp.p: With a smile .Shut up , Harold .

div.stage: The AMAH with nods , smiles and bows , goes out .

sp.speaker: KNOX
sp.p: Harry , my poor friend , is it possible that you have an assignation ?

sp.speaker: HARRY
sp.p: What is possible is that if you do n't get out quick I 'll throw you out .

sp.speaker: KNOX
sp.p: Why did n't you say you were expecting a girl ?

sp.speaker: HARRY
sp.p: I 'm not ; I 'm expecting a lady .

sp.speaker: KNOX
sp.p: Are you sure you know how to behave ? If you 'd like me to stay and see you do n't do the wrong thing I 'll chuck my tennis . I 'm always ready to sacrifice myself for a friend .

sp.speaker: HARRY
sp.p: Has it struck you that the distance from the verandah to the street is very considerable ?

sp.speaker: KNOX
sp.p: And the pavement is hard . I flatter myself I can take a hint . I wonder where the devil my pin is . I left it on the table .

sp.speaker: HARRY
sp.p: I expect Wu put it away .

sp.speaker: KNOX
sp.p: It 's much more likely that old woman pinched it .

sp.speaker: HARRY
sp.p: Oh , nonsense . She would n't dream of such a thing . I believe Mrs. Rathbone 's had her for ages .

sp.speaker: KNOX
sp.p: Who is Mrs. Rathbone ?

sp.speaker: HARRY
sp.p: Not wishing to be questioned .A friend of mine .

div.stage: GEORGE CONWAY comes in . He is a tall , dark man in the early thirties . He is a handsome , well-built fellow , of a somewhat rugged appearance , but urbane and self-assured .

sp.speaker: GEORGE
sp.p: May I come in ?

sp.speaker: HARRY
sp.p: Eagerly , shaking him warmly by the hand .At last . By Jove , it 's good to see you again . You know Knox , do n't you ?

sp.speaker: GEORGE
sp.p: I think so .

sp.speaker: KNOX
sp.p: I wash bottles in the B . A. T. I do n't expect the legation bloods to be aware of my existence .

lg.stage: With a twinkle in his eye .
lg.l: I do n't know that an Assistant
Chinese Secretary is such a blood as all that .

sp.speaker: KNOX
sp.p: You 've just been down to Fuchow , have n't you ?

sp.speaker: GEORGE
sp.p: Yes , I only got back this morning .

sp.speaker: KNOX
sp.p: Did you see Freddy Baker by any chance ?

sp.speaker: GEORGE
sp.p: Yes , poor chap .

sp.speaker: KNOX
sp.p: Oh , I 've got no pity for him . He 's just a damned fool .

sp.speaker: HARRY
sp.p: Why ?

sp.speaker: KNOX
sp.p: Have n't you heard ? He 's married a half-caste .

sp.speaker: HARRY
sp.p: What of it ? I believe she 's a very pretty girl .

sp.speaker: KNOX
sp.p: I daresay she is . But hang it all , he need n't have married her .

sp.speaker: GEORGE
sp.p: I do n't think it was a very wise thing to do .

sp.speaker: HARRY
sp.p: I should have thought all those prejudices were out of date . Why should n't a man marry a half-caste if he wants to ?

sp.speaker: KNOX
sp.p: It can n't be very nice to have a wife whom even the missionary ladies turn up their noses at .

sp.speaker: HARRY
sp.p: With a shrug of the shoulders .You wait till Freddy 's number one in Hankow and can entertain . I bet the white ladies will be glad enough to know his missus then .

lg.l: Yes , but that 's just it . He 'll never get a good job with a
Eurasian wife .

sp.speaker: HARRY
sp.p: He 's in Jardine 's , is n't he ? Do you mean to say it 's going to handicap a man in a shipping firm because he 's married a woman who 's partly Chinese ?

sp.speaker: GEORGE
sp.p: Of course it is . Jardine 's are about the most important firm in China and the manager of one of their principal branches has definite social obligations . Freddy Baker will be sent to twopenny halfpenny outports where his wife does n't matter .

sp.speaker: KNOX
sp.p: I think he 's damned lucky if he 's not asked to resign .

sp.speaker: HARRY
sp.p: It 's cruel . His wife may be a charming and cultivated woman .

sp.speaker: KNOX
sp.p: Have you ever known a half-caste that was ?

sp.speaker: HARRY
sp.p: I have .

sp.speaker: KNOX
sp.p: Well , I 've been in this country for seven years and I 've never met one , male or female , that did n't give me the shivers .

sp.speaker: HARRY
sp.p: I 've no patience with you . You 're a perfect damned fool .

sp.speaker: KNOX
sp.p: A little surprised , but quite good-humoured .You 're getting rather excited , are n't you ?

sp.speaker: HARRY
sp.p: Hotly .I hate injustice .

sp.speaker: GEORGE
sp.p: Do you think it really is injustice ? The English are not an unkindly race . If they 've got a down on half-castes there are probably very good grounds for it .

sp.speaker: HARRY
sp.p: What are they ?

sp.speaker: KNOX
sp.p: We do n't much like their morals , but we can n't stick their manners .

sp.speaker: GEORGE
sp.p: Somehow or other they seem to inherit all the bad qualities of the two races from which they spring and none of the good ones . I 'm sure there are exceptions , but on the whole the Eurasian is vulgar and noisy . He can n't tell the truth if he tries .

sp.speaker: KNOX
sp.p: To do him justice , he seldom tries .

sp.speaker: GEORGE
sp.p: He 's as vain as a peacock . He 'll cringe when he 's afraid of you and he 'll bully when he 's not . You can never rely on him . He 's crooked from the crown of his German hat to the toes of his American boots .

sp.speaker: KNOX
sp.p: Straight from the shoulder . Take the count , old man .

sp.speaker: HARRY
sp.p: Frigidly .Ought n't you to be going ?

sp.speaker: KNOX
sp.p: Smiling .No , but I will .

sp.speaker: HARRY
sp.p: I 'm sorry if I was rude to you just now , old man .

sp.speaker: KNOX
sp.p: He goes out .Silly ass , you 've broken no bones ; my self-esteem , thank God , is unimpaired .

lg.l: I say , I 'm awfully glad you 're back , George . You can n't think how
I miss you when you 're away .

sp.speaker: GEORGE
sp.p: As soon as the shooting starts we 'll try and get two or three days together in the country .

sp.speaker: HARRY
sp.p: Yes , that would be jolly .Calling .Wu .

sp.speaker: WU
sp.p: Outside .Ye ’ .

sp.speaker: HARRY
sp.p: Bring tea for three .

sp.speaker: GEORGE
sp.p: Who is the third ?

sp.speaker: HARRY
sp.p: When you said you could come round I asked somebody I want you very much to meet .

sp.speaker: GEORGE
sp.p: Who is that ?

sp.speaker: HARRY
sp.p: Mrs. Rathbone ... I 'm going to be married to her and we want you to be our best man .

sp.speaker: GEORGE
sp.p: Harry .

sp.speaker: HARRY
sp.p: Boyishly .I thought you 'd be surprised .

sp.speaker: GEORGE
sp.p: My dear old boy , I am so glad . I hope you 'll be awfully happy .

sp.speaker: HARRY
sp.p: I 'm awfully happy now .

sp.speaker: GEORGE
sp.p: Why have you kept it so dark ?

lg.l: I did n't want to say anything till it was all settled . Besides ,
I 've only known her six weeks . I met her when I was down in Shanghai ....

sp.speaker: GEORGE
sp.p: Is she a widow ?

sp.speaker: HARRY
sp.p: Yes , she was married to an American in the F. M. S .

sp.speaker: GEORGE
sp.p: Is she American ?

sp.speaker: HARRY
sp.p: Only by marriage . I 'm afraid she did n't have a very happy married life .

sp.speaker: GEORGE
sp.p: Poor thing . I think I 'd take a small bet that you wo n't beat her .

sp.speaker: HARRY
sp.p: I mean to try my best to make her happy .

sp.speaker: GEORGE
sp.p: You old fool , I 've never known a man who was likely to make a better husband .

sp.speaker: HARRY
sp.p: I 'm most awfully in love with her , George .

sp.speaker: GEORGE
sp.p: Is n't that ripping ? How old is she ?

sp.speaker: HARRY
sp.p: Only twenty-two . She 's the loveliest thing you ever saw .

sp.speaker: GEORGE
sp.p: And is she in love with you ?

sp.speaker: HARRY
sp.p: She says so .

sp.speaker: GEORGE
sp.p: She damned well ought to be .

sp.speaker: HARRY
sp.p: I do hope you 'll like her , George .

sp.speaker: GEORGE
sp.p: Of course I shall . You 're not the sort of chap to fall in love with a woman who is n't nice .

div.stage: HARRY walks up and down for a moment restlessly .

sp.speaker: HARRY
sp.p: Will you have a whisky and soda ?

sp.speaker: GEORGE
sp.p: No , thanks ... I 'll wait for tea .

sp.speaker: HARRY
sp.p: She ought to be here in a moment .Suddenly making up his mind .It 's no good beating about the bush . I may as well tell you at once . Her — her mother was Chinese .

lg.l: Oh , Harry .
I wish
I had n't said all that I did just now .

sp.speaker: HARRY
sp.p: Of course you did n't know .

lg.l: I should have had to say something very like it ,
Harry . But I should n't have put it so bluntly .

sp.speaker: HARRY
sp.p: You said yourself there were exceptions .

sp.speaker: GEORGE
sp.p: I know .Distressed .Wo n't your people be rather upset ?

sp.speaker: HARRY
sp.p: I do n't see how it can matter to them . They 're nine thousand miles away .

sp.speaker: GEORGE
sp.p: Who was her father ?

sp.speaker: HARRY
sp.p: Oh , he was a merchant . He 's dead . And her mother is too .

sp.speaker: GEORGE
sp.p: That 's something . I do n't think you 'd much like having a Chinese mother-in-law about the place .

sp.speaker: HARRY
sp.p: George , you wo n't let it make any difference , will you ? We 've known one another all our lives .

sp.speaker: GEORGE
sp.p: My dear old chap , as far as I 'm concerned I should n't care if you married the first cousin of the Ace of Spades . I do n't want you to make a hash of things .

sp.speaker: HARRY
sp.p: Wait till you see her . She 's the most fascinating thing you ever met .

sp.speaker: GEORGE
sp.p: Yes , they can be charming . I was awfully in love with a half — with a Eurasian girl myself years ago . It was before you came out to the country . I wanted to marry her .

sp.speaker: HARRY
sp.p: Why did n't you ?

sp.speaker: GEORGE
sp.p: It was up in Chung-king . I 'd just been appointed vice-consul . I was only twenty-three . The Minister wired from Peking that I 'd have to resign if I did . I had n't a bob except my salary and they transferred me to Canton to get me away .

lg.l: It 's different for you . You 're in the service and you may be
Minister one of these days . I 'm only a merchant .

sp.speaker: GEORGE
sp.p: Even for you there 'll be difficulties , you know . Has it occurred to you that the white ladies wo n't be very nice ?

sp.speaker: HARRY
sp.p: I can do without their society .

sp.speaker: GEORGE
sp.p: You must know some people . It means you 'll have to hobnob with Eurasian clerks and their wives . I 'm afraid you 'll find it pretty rotten .

sp.speaker: HARRY
sp.p: If you 'll stick to me I do n't care .

sp.speaker: GEORGE
sp.p: I suppose you 've absolutely made up your mind ?

sp.speaker: HARRY
sp.p: Absolutely .

sp.speaker: GEORGE
sp.p: In that case I 've got nothing more to say . You can n't expect me not to be a little disappointed , but after all the chief thing is your happiness , and whatever I can do I will . You can put your shirt on that .

sp.speaker: HARRY
sp.p: You 're a brick , George .

sp.speaker: GEORGE
sp.p: The little lady ought to be here , ought n't she ?

sp.speaker: HARRY
sp.p: I think I hear her on the stairs .

div.stage: He goes to the entrance and then out . WU brings in the tea and sets it on the table . GEORGE walks over to the parapet and looks thoughtfully before him . There is a sound of voices in the adjoining room .

sp.speaker: HARRY
sp.p: Outside .Come in ; he 's on the verandah .

sp.speaker: DAISY
sp.p: Outside .One brief look in the glass and then I 'm ready .

div.stage: HARRY enters .

sp.speaker: HARRY
sp.p: She 's just coming .

sp.speaker: GEORGE
sp.p: I bet she 's powdering her nose .

sp.speaker: DAISY
sp.p: Here I am .

div.stage: DAISY enters . SHE is an extremely pretty woman , beautifully , perhaps a little showily , dressed . She has a pale , very clear , slightly sallow skin , and beautiful dark eyes . There is only the very faintest suspicion in them of the Chinese slant . Her hair is abundant and black .

sp.speaker: HARRY
sp.p: This is George Conway , Daisy .

div.stage: GEORGE stares at her . At first he is not quite sure that he recognizes her , then suddenly he does , but only the slightest movement of the eyes betrays him .

sp.speaker: DAISY
sp.p: How do you do . I told Harry I had an idea I must have met you somewhere . I do n't think I have after all .

sp.speaker: HARRY
sp.p: George flatters himself he 's not easily forgotten .

sp.speaker: DAISY
sp.p: But I 've heard so much about you from Harry that I feel as though we were old friends .

sp.speaker: GEORGE
sp.p: It 's very kind of you to say so .

sp.speaker: HARRY
sp.p: Supposing you poured out the tea , Daisy .

sp.speaker: GEORGE
sp.p: I 'm dying for a cup .

div.stage: She sits down and proceeds to do so .

sp.speaker: DAISY
sp.p: Harry is very anxious that you should like me .

sp.speaker: HARRY
sp.p: George and I have known one another since we were kids . His people and mine live quite close to one another at home .

sp.speaker: DAISY
sp.p: But I 'm not blaming you . I 'm only wondering how I shall ingratiate myself with him .

sp.speaker: HARRY
sp.p: He looks rather severe , but he is n't really . I think you 've only got to be your natural charming self .

sp.speaker: DAISY
sp.p: Have you told him about the house ?

sp.speaker: HARRY
sp.p: No .To George .You know the temple the Harrisons used to have . We 've taken that .

sp.speaker: GEORGE
sp.p: Oh , it 's a ripping place . But wo n't you find it rather a nuisance to have those old monks on the top of you all the time ?

sp.speaker: HARRY
sp.p: Oh , I do n't think so . Our part is quite separate , you know , and the Harrisons made it very comfortable .

div.stage: HAROLD KNOX comes in . He has changed into tennis things .

sp.speaker: KNOX
sp.p: I say , Harry ...He sees DAISY .Oh , I beg your pardon .

sp.speaker: HARRY
sp.p: Mr. Knox — Mrs. Rathbone .

div.stage: KNOX gives her a curt nod , but she holds out her hand affably . He takes it .

sp.speaker: DAISY
sp.p: How do you do .

sp.speaker: KNOX
sp.p: I 'm sorry to disturb you , Harry , but old Ku Faung Min is downstairs and wants to see you .

sp.speaker: HARRY
sp.p: Tell him to go to blazes . The office is closed .

sp.speaker: KNOX
sp.p: He 's going to Hankow to-night and he says he must see you before he goes . He 's got some big order to give .

sp.speaker: HARRY
sp.p: Oh , curse him . I know what he is . He 'll keep me talking for half an hour . D'you mind if I leave you ?

sp.speaker: DAISY
sp.p: Of course not . It 'll give me a chance of making Mr. Conway 's acquaintance .

sp.speaker: HARRY
sp.p: I 'll get rid of him as quickly as I can .

div.stage: He goes out accompanied by Knox .

sp.speaker: KNOX
sp.p: As he goes .Good-bye .

div.stage: GEORGE looks at DAISY for a moment . She smiles at him . There is a silence .

sp.speaker: GEORGE
sp.p: Why did n't you warn me that it was you I was going to meet ?

sp.speaker: DAISY
sp.p: I did n't know what you 'd say about me to Harry if you knew .

sp.speaker: GEORGE
sp.p: It was rather a risk , was n't it ? Supposing I 'd blurted out the truth .

sp.speaker: DAISY
sp.p: I trusted to your diplomatic training . Besides , I 'd prepared for it . I told him I thought I 'd met you .

lg.l: Harry and I have been pals all our lives . I brought him out to
China and I got him his job . When he had cholera he would have died if
I had n't pulled him through .

sp.speaker: DAISY
sp.p: I know . And in return he worships the ground you tread on . I 've never known one man think so much of another as he does of you .

sp.speaker: GEORGE
sp.p: All that 's rot , of course . Sometimes I do n't know how I 'm going to live up to the good opinion Harry has of me . But when you 've done so much for a pal as I have for him it gives you an awful sense of responsibility towards him .

sp.speaker: DAISY
sp.p: What do you mean by that ?

div.stage: A short pause .

sp.speaker: GEORGE
sp.p: I 'm not going to let you marry him .

sp.speaker: DAISY
sp.p: He 's so much in love with me that he does n't know what to do with himself .

sp.speaker: GEORGE
sp.p: I know he is . But if you were in love with him you would n't be so sure of it .

sp.speaker: DAISY
sp.p: With a sudden change of tone .Why not ? I was sure of your love . And God knows I was in love with you .

div.stage: GEORGE makes a gesture of dismay . He is taken aback for a moment , but he quickly recovers .

sp.speaker: GEORGE
sp.p: You do n't know what sort of a man Harry is . He 's not like the fellows you 've been used to . He 's never knocked around as most of us do . He 's always been as straight as a die .

sp.speaker: DAISY
sp.p: I know .

sp.speaker: GEORGE
sp.p: Have mercy on him . Even if there were nothing else against you he 's not the sort of chap for you to marry . He 's awfully English .

sp.speaker: DAISY
sp.p: If he does n't mind marrying a Eurasian I really do n't see what business it is of yours .

sp.speaker: GEORGE
sp.p: But you know very well that that is n't the only thing against you .

sp.speaker: DAISY
sp.p: I have n't an idea what you mean .

sp.speaker: GEORGE
sp.p: Have n't you ? You forget the war . When we heard there was a very pretty young woman , apparently with plenty of money , living at the Hong Kong Hotel on very familiar terms with a lot of naval fellows , it became our business to make enquiries . I think I know everything there is against you .

sp.speaker: DAISY
sp.p: Have you any right to make use of information you 've acquired officially ?

sp.speaker: GEORGE
sp.p: Do n't be a fool , Daisy .

sp.speaker: DAISY
sp.p: Passionately .Tell him then . You 'll break his heart . You 'll make him utterly wretched . But he 'll marry me all the same . When a man 's as much in love as he is he 'll forgive everything .

sp.speaker: GEORGE
sp.p: I think it 's horrible . If you loved him you could n't marry him . It 's heartless .

sp.speaker: DAISY
sp.p: Violently .How dare you say that ? You . You . You know what I am . Yes , it 's all true . I do n't know what you know but it can n't be worse than the truth . And whose fault is it ? Yours . If I 'm rotten it 's you who made me rotten .

sp.speaker: GEORGE
sp.p: I ? No . You 've got no right to say that . It 's cruel . It 's infamous .

sp.speaker: DAISY
sp.p: I 've touched you at last , have I ? Because you know it 's true . Do n't you remember when I first came to Chung-king ? I was seventeen . My father had sent me to England to school when I was seven . I never saw him for ten years . And at last he wrote and said I was to come back to China . You came and met me on the boat and told me my father had had a stroke and was dead . You took me to the Presbyterian mission .

sp.speaker: GEORGE
sp.p: That was my job . I was awfully sorry for you .

sp.speaker: DAISY
sp.p: And then in a day or two you came and told me that my father had n't left anything and what there was went to his relations in England .

sp.speaker: GEORGE
sp.p: Naturally he did n't expect to die .

sp.speaker: DAISY
sp.p: Passionately .If he was going to leave me like that why did n't he let me stay with my Chinese mother ? Why did he bring me up like a lady ? Oh , it was cruel .

sp.speaker: GEORGE
sp.p: Yes . It was unpardonable .

sp.speaker: DAISY
sp.p: I was so lonely and so frightened . You seemed to be sorry for me . You were the only person who was really kind to me . You were practically the first man I 'd known . I loved you . I thought you loved me . Oh , say that you loved me then , George .

sp.speaker: GEORGE
sp.p: You know I did .

sp.speaker: DAISY
sp.p: I was very innocent in those days . I thought that when two people loved one another they married . I was n't a Eurasian then , George . I was like any other English girl . If you 'd married me I should n't be what I am now . But they took you away from me . You never even said good-bye to me . You wrote and told me you 'd been transferred to Canton .

sp.speaker: GEORGE
sp.p: I could n't say good-bye to you , Daisy . They said that if I married you I 'd have to leave the service . I was absolutely penniless . They dinned it into my ears that if a white man marries a Eurasian he 's done for . I would n't listen to them , but in my heart I knew it was true .

sp.speaker: DAISY
sp.p: I do n't blame you . You wanted to get on , and you have , have n't you ? You 're Assistant Chinese Secretary already and Harry says you 'll be Minister before you 've done . It seems rather hard that I should have had to pay the price .

sp.speaker: GEORGE
sp.p: Daisy , you 'll never know what anguish I suffered . I can n't expect you to care . It 's very natural if you hate me . I was ambitious . I did n't want to be a failure . I knew that it was madness to marry you . I had to kill my love . I could n't . It was stronger than I was . At last I could n't help myself . I made up my mind to chuck everything and take the consequences . I was just starting for Chung-king when I heard you were living in Shanghai with a rich Chinaman .

div.stage: DAISY gives a little moan . There is a silence .

sp.speaker: DAISY
sp.p: They hated me at the mission . They found fault with me from morning till night . They blamed me because you wanted to marry me and they treated me as if I was a designing cat . When you went away they heaved a sigh of relief . Then they started to convert me . They thought I 'd better become a school teacher . They hated me because I was seventeen . They hated me because I was pretty . Oh , the brutes . They killed all the religion I 'd got . There was only one person who seemed to care if I was alive or dead . That was my mother . Oh , I was so ashamed the first time I saw her . At school in England I 'd told them so often that she was a Chinese princess that I almost believed it myself . My mother was a dirty little ugly Chinawoman . I 'd forgotten all my Chinese and I had to talk to her in English . She asked me if I 'd like to go to Shanghai with her . I was ready to do anything in the world to get away from the mission and I thought in Shanghai I should n't be so far away from you . They did n't want me to go , but they could n't keep me against my will . When we got to Shanghai she sold me to Lee Tai Cheng for two thousand dollars .

sp.speaker: GEORGE
sp.p: How terrible .

sp.speaker: DAISY
sp.p: I 've never had a chance . Oh , George , is n't it possible for a woman to turn over a new leaf ? You say that Harry 's good and kind . Do n't you see what that means to me ? Because he 'll think me good I shall be good . After all , he could n't have fallen in love with me if I 'd been entirely worthless . I hate the life I 've led . I want to go straight . I swear I 'll make him a good wife . Oh , George , if you ever loved me have pity on me . If Harry does n't marry me I 'm done .

sp.speaker: GEORGE
sp.p: How can a marriage be happy that 's founded on a tissue of lies ?

sp.speaker: DAISY
sp.p: I 've never told Harry a single lie .

sp.speaker: GEORGE
sp.p: You told him you had n't been happily married .

sp.speaker: DAISY
sp.p: That was n't a lie .

sp.speaker: GEORGE
sp.p: You have n't been married at all .

sp.speaker: DAISY
sp.p: With a roguish look .Well then , I have n't been happily married , have I ?

sp.speaker: GEORGE
sp.p: Who was this fellow Rathbone ?

lg.l: He was an American in business at Singapore . I met him in
Shanghai . I hated Lee . Rathbone asked me to go to Singapore with him and
I went . I lived with him for four years .

sp.speaker: GEORGE
sp.p: Then you went back to Lee Tai Cheng .

sp.speaker: DAISY
sp.p: Rathbone died . There was nothing else to do . My mother was always nagging me to go back to him . He 's rich and she makes a good thing out of it .

sp.speaker: GEORGE
sp.p: I thought she was dead .

sp.speaker: DAISY
sp.p: No . I told Harry she was because I thought it would make it easier for him .

sp.speaker: GEORGE
sp.p: She is n't with you now , is she ?

sp.speaker: DAISY
sp.p: No , she lives at Ichang . She does n't bother me as long as I send her something every month .

sp.speaker: GEORGE
sp.p: Why did you tell Harry that you were twenty-two ? It 's ten years since you came to China and you were seventeen then .

sp.speaker: DAISY
sp.p: With a twinkle in her eye .Any woman of my age will tell you that seventeen and ten are twenty-two .

div.stage: GEORGE does not smile . With frowning brow he walks up and down .

sp.speaker: GEORGE
sp.p: Oh , I wish to God I knew nothing about you . I can n't bring myself to tell him and yet how can I let him marry you in absolute ignorance ? Oh , Daisy , for your sake as well as for his I beseech you to tell him the whole truth and let him decide for himself .

sp.speaker: DAISY
sp.p: And break his heart ? There 's not a missionary who believes in God as he believes in me . If he loses his trust in me he loses everything . Tell him if you think you must , if you have no pity , if you have no regret for all the shame and misery you brought on me , you , you , you — but if you do , I swear , I swear to God that I shall kill myself . I wo n't go back to that hateful life .

div.stage: He looks at her earnestly for a moment .

sp.speaker: GEORGE
sp.p: I do n't know if I 'm doing right or wrong . I shall tell him nothing .

div.stage: DAISY gives a deep sigh of relief , HARRY comes in .

sp.speaker: HARRY
sp.p: I say , I 'm awfully sorry to have been so long . I could n't get the old blighter to go .

sp.speaker: DAISY
sp.p: With complete self-control .If I say you 've been an age it 'll look as though Mr. Conway had been boring me .

sp.speaker: HARRY
sp.p: I hope you 've made friends .

sp.speaker: DAISY
sp.p: To GEORGE .Have we ?

sp.speaker: GEORGE
sp.p: I hope so . But now I think I must bolt . I have a long Chinese document to translate .Holding out his hand to DAISY .I hope you 'll both be very happy .

sp.speaker: DAISY
sp.p: I think I 'm going to like you .

sp.speaker: GEORGE
sp.p: Good-bye , Harry , old man .

sp.speaker: HARRY
sp.p: I shall see you later on in the club , sha'n ' t I ?

sp.speaker: GEORGE
sp.p: If I can get through my work .

div.stage: He goes out .

sp.speaker: HARRY
sp.p: What have you and George been talking about ?

sp.speaker: DAISY
sp.p: We discussed the house . It 'll be great fun buying the things for it .

sp.speaker: HARRY
sp.p: I could have killed that old Chink for keeping me so long . I grudge every minute that I spend away from you .

sp.speaker: DAISY
sp.p: It 's nice to be loved .

sp.speaker: HARRY
sp.p: You do love me a little , do n't you ?

sp.speaker: DAISY
sp.p: A little more than a little , my lamb .

sp.speaker: HARRY
sp.p: I wish I were more worth your while . You 've made me feel so dissatisfied with myself . I 'm such a rotter .

sp.speaker: DAISY
sp.p: You 're not going to disagree with me already .

sp.speaker: HARRY
sp.p: What about ?

sp.speaker: DAISY
sp.p: About you . I think you 're a perfect duck .

div.stage: The AMAH appears .

sp.speaker: HARRY
sp.p: Hulloa , who 's this ?

sp.speaker: DAISY
sp.p: Oh , it 's my amah .

sp.speaker: HARRY
sp.p: I did n't recognize her for a moment .

sp.speaker: DAISY
sp.p: She does n't approve of my being alone with strange gentlemen . She looks after me as if I was a child of ten .

sp.speaker: AMAH
sp.p: Velly late , missy Daisy . Time you come along .

sp.speaker: HARRY
sp.p: Oh , nonsense .

lg.l: She wants me to go and be fitted . She never lets me go out in
Peking alone .

sp.speaker: HARRY
sp.p: She 's quite right .

sp.speaker: DAISY
sp.p: Amah , come and be introduced to the gentleman . He 's going to be your master now .

sp.speaker: AMAH
sp.p: Smiling , with little nods .Velly nice gentleman . You keep missy Daisy old amah — yes ? Velly good amah — yes ?

sp.speaker: DAISY
sp.p: She 's been with me ever since I was a child .

lg.l: Of course we 'll keep her . She was with you when you were in
Singapore ?

sp.speaker: DAISY
sp.p: With a little sigh .Yes , I do n't know what I should have done without her sometimes .

sp.speaker: HARRY
sp.p: Oh , Daisy , I do want to make you forget all the unhappiness you have suffered .He takes her in his arms and kisses her on the lips . The AMAH chuckles to herself silently .END OF SCENE II .

div.head: SCENE III

stage.stage: SCENE : The Temple of Fidelity and Virtuous Inclination . The courtyard of the temple is shown . At the back is the sanctuary in which is seen the altar table ; on this are two large vases in each of which are seven lotus flowers , gilt but discoloured by incense , and in the middle there is a sand-box in which are burning joss-sticks ; behind is the image of Buddha . The sanctuary can be closed by huge doors . These are now open . A flight of steps leads up to it .

A service is finishing . The monks are seen on each side of the altar kneeling in two rows . They are clad in grey gowns and their heads are shaven . They sing the invocation to Buddha , repeating the same words over and over again in a monotonous chaunt . DAISY stands outside the sanctuary door , on the steps , listlessly . The AMAH is squatting by her side . Now the service ends ; the monks form a procession and two by two , still singing , come down the steps and go out . A tiny acolyte blows out the oil lamps and with an effort shuts the temple doors .
DAISY comes down the steps and sits on one of the lower ones . She is dreadfully bored .

sp.speaker: AMAH
sp.p: What is the matter with my pletty one ?

sp.speaker: DAISY
sp.p: What should be the matter ?

sp.speaker: AMAH
sp.p: With a snigger .Hi , hi . Old amah got velly good eyes in her head .

sp.speaker: DAISY
sp.p: As though talking to herself .I 've got a husband who adores me and a nice house to live in . I 've got a position and as much money as I want . I 'm safe . I 'm respectable . I ought to be happy .

sp.speaker: AMAH
sp.p: I say , Harry no good , what for you wanchee marry ? You say , I wanchee marry , I wanchee marry ? Well , you married . What you want now ?

sp.speaker: DAISY
sp.p: They say life is short . Good God , how long the days are .

sp.speaker: AMAH
sp.p: You want pony — Harry give you pony . You want jade ring — Harry give you jade ring . You want sable coat — Harry give you sable coat . Why you not happy ?

sp.speaker: DAISY
sp.p: I never said I was n't happy .

sp.speaker: AMAH
sp.p: Hi , hi .

sp.speaker: DAISY
sp.p: If you laugh like that I 'll kill you .

sp.speaker: AMAH
sp.p: You no kill old amah . You want old amah . I got something velly pletty for my little Daisy flower .

sp.speaker: DAISY
sp.p: Do n't be an old fool . I 'm not a child any more .Desperately .I 'm growing older , older , older . And every day is just like every other day . I might as well be dead .

sp.speaker: AMAH
sp.p: Look this pletty present old amah have got .

div.stage: She takes a jade necklace out of her sleeve and puts it , smiling , into DAISY 'S hand .

sp.speaker: DAISY
sp.p: With sudden vivacity ,Oh , what a lovely chain . It 's beautiful jade . How much do they want for it ?

sp.speaker: AMAH
sp.p: It 's a present for my little Daisy .

sp.speaker: DAISY
sp.p: For me ? It must have cost five hundred dollars . Who is it from ?

sp.speaker: AMAH
sp.p: To-day is my little Daisy 's wedding-day . She have married one year . Perhaps old amah want to give her little flower present .

sp.speaker: DAISY
sp.p: YOU ! Have you ever given me anything but a beating ?

sp.speaker: AMAH
sp.p: Lee Tai Cheng pay me necklace and say you give to Daisy .

sp.speaker: DAISY
sp.p: You old hag .She flings the necklace away violently .

lg.l: You silly . Worth plenty money . You no wanchee , I sell rich
Amelican .

div.stage: She is just going after the necklace , when DAISY catches her violently by the arm .

lg.l: How dare you ? How dare you ? I told you that you were never to let
Lee Tai speak to you again .
You very angry , Daisy . You very angry before , but you go back to
Lee Tai ; he think perhaps you go back again .

sp.speaker: DAISY
sp.p: Tell him that I loathe the sight of him . Tell him that if I were starving I would n't take a penny from him . Tell him that if he dares to come round here I 'll have him beaten till he screams .

sp.speaker: AMAH
sp.p: Hi , hi .

sp.speaker: DAISY
sp.p: And you leave me alone , will you . Harry hates you . I 've only got to say a word and he 'll kick you out in five minutes .

sp.speaker: AMAH
sp.p: What would my little Daisy do without old amah , hi , hi ? What for you no talkee true ? You think old amah no got eyes ?With a cunning , arch look .I got something make you very glad .She takes a note out of her sleeve .

sp.speaker: DAISY
sp.p: What 's that ?

sp.speaker: AMAH
sp.p: I got letter .

sp.speaker: DAISY
sp.p: Snatching it from her .Give it me . How dare you hide it ?

sp.speaker: AMAH
sp.p: Have come when you long Harry . I think perhaps you no wanchee read when Harry there .DAISY tears it open .What he say ?

sp.speaker: DAISY
sp.p: Reading .“ I 'm awfully sorry I can n't dine with you on Thursday , but I 'm engaged . I 've just remembered it 's your wedding-day and I 'll look in for a minute . Ask Harry if he 'd like to ride with me . ”

sp.speaker: AMAH
sp.p: Is that all ?

sp.speaker: DAISY
sp.p: “ Yours ever . George Conway . ”

sp.speaker: AMAH
sp.p: You love him very much , George Conway ?

sp.speaker: DAISY
sp.p: Taking no notice of her , passionately .At last . I have n't seen him for ten days . Ten mortal days . Oh , I want him . I want him .

sp.speaker: AMAH
sp.p: Why you no talkee old amah ?

sp.speaker: DAISY
sp.p: Desperately .I can n't help myself . Oh , I love him so . What shall I do ? I can n't live without him . If you do n't want me to die make him love me .

sp.speaker: AMAH
sp.p: You see , you want old amah .

sp.speaker: DAISY
sp.p: Oh , I 'm so unhappy . I think I shall go mad .

sp.speaker: AMAH
sp.p: Sh , sh . Perhaps he love you too .

sp.speaker: DAISY
sp.p: Never . He hates me . Why does he avoid me ? He never comes here . At first he was always looking in . He used to come out and dine two or three days a week . What have I done to him ? He only comes now because he does not want to offend Harry . Harry , Harry , what do I care for Harry ?

sp.speaker: AMAH
sp.p: Sh . Do n't let him see . Give amah the letter .

div.stage: She snatches it from DAISY and hides it in her dress as HARRY comes in . DAISY pulls herself together .

sp.speaker: HARRY
sp.p: I say , Daisy , I 've just had the ponies saddled . Put on your habit and let 's go for a ride .

sp.speaker: DAISY
sp.p: I 've got a headache .

sp.speaker: HARRY
sp.p: Oh , my poor child . Why do n't you lie down ?

sp.speaker: DAISY
sp.p: I thought I was better in the air . But there 's no reason why you should n't ride .

sp.speaker: HARRY
sp.p: Oh , no , I wo n't ride without you .

lg.l: Why on earth not ? It 'll do you good . You know when my head 's bad
I only want to be left alone . Your pony wants exercising .

sp.speaker: HARRY
sp.p: The boy can do that .

sp.speaker: DAISY
sp.p: Trying to conceal her growing exasperation .Please do as I ask . I 'd rather you went .

sp.speaker: HARRY
sp.p: Laughing .Of course if you 're so anxious to get rid of me ....

sp.speaker: DAISY
sp.p: Smiling .I can n't bear that you should be done out of your ride . If you wo n't go alone you 'll just force me to come with you .

sp.speaker: HARRY
sp.p: I 'll go . Give me a kiss before I do .She puts up her lips to his .I 'm almost ashamed of myself , I 'm just as madly in love with you as the day we were married .

sp.speaker: DAISY
sp.p: You are a dear . Have a nice ride , and when you come back I shall be all right .

sp.speaker: HARRY
sp.p: That 's ripping . I sha n't be very long .

div.stage: He goes out . The lightness , the smile , with which she has spoken to Harry disappear as he goes , and she looks worried and anxious .

sp.speaker: DAISY
sp.p: Supposing they meet ?

sp.speaker: AMAH
sp.p: No can . Harry go out back way .

sp.speaker: DAISY
sp.p: Yes , I suppose he will . I wish he 'd be quick .Violently .I must see George .

sp.speaker: AMAH
sp.p: Picking up the necklace .Velly pletty necklace . You silly girl . Why you no take ?

sp.speaker: DAISY
sp.p: Oh , damn , why can n't you leave me alone ?Listening .What on earth is Harry doing ? I thought the pony was saddled .

sp.speaker: AMAH
sp.p: Looking at the necklace .What shall I do with this ?

sp.speaker: DAISY
sp.p: Throw it in the dust-bin .

sp.speaker: AMAH
sp.p: Lee Tai no likee that very much .

sp.speaker: DAISY
sp.p: Hearing the sound of the pony , with a sigh of relief .He 's gone . Now I 'm safe . Where 's my bag ?She takes a little mirror out of it and looks at herself .I look perfectly hideous .

sp.speaker: AMAH
sp.p: Do n't be silly . You velly pletty girl .

sp.speaker: DAISY
sp.p: Her ears all alert .There 's someone riding along .

sp.speaker: AMAH
sp.p: That not pony . That Peking cart .

sp.speaker: DAISY
sp.p: You old fool , I tell you it 's a pony . At last . Oh , my heart 's beating so .... It 's stopping at the gate . It 's George . Oh , I love him . I love him .To the AMAH , stamping her foot .What are you waiting for ? I do n't want you here now , and do n't listen , d'you hear . Get out , get out .

sp.speaker: AMAH
sp.p: All-light . My go away .

div.stage: The AMAH slinks away . DAISY stands waiting for GEORGE , holding her hands to her heart as though to stop the anguish of its beating . She makes a great effort at self-control as GEORGE enters . He is in riding kit . He has a bunch of orchids in his hand .

sp.speaker: GEORGE
sp.p: Hulloa , what are you doing here ?

sp.speaker: DAISY
sp.p: I was tired of sitting in the drawing-room .

sp.speaker: GEORGE
sp.p: I remembered it was your wedding-day . I 've brought you a few flowers .She takes them with both hands .

sp.speaker: DAISY
sp.p: Thank you . That is kind of you .

sp.speaker: GEORGE
sp.p: Gravely .I hope you 'll always be very happy . I hope you 'll allow me to say how grateful I am that you 've given Harry so much happiness .

sp.speaker: DAISY
sp.p: You 're very solemn . One would almost think you 'd prepared that pretty speech beforehand .

sp.speaker: GEORGE
sp.p: Trying to take it lightly .I 'm sorry if it did n't sound natural . I can promise you it was sincere .

sp.speaker: DAISY
sp.p: Shall we sit down ?

sp.speaker: GEORGE
sp.p: I think we ought to go for our ride while the light lasts . I 'll come in and have a drink on the way back .

sp.speaker: DAISY
sp.p: Harry 's out .

lg.l: Is he ? I sent you a note this morning . I said I could n't dine on
Thursday and I 'd come and fetch Harry for a ride this afternoon .

sp.speaker: DAISY
sp.p: I did n't tell him .

sp.speaker: GEORGE
sp.p: No ?

sp.speaker: DAISY
sp.p: I do n't see you very often nowadays .

sp.speaker: GEORGE
sp.p: There 's an awful lot of work to do just now . They lead me a dog 's life at the legation .

sp.speaker: DAISY
sp.p: Even at night ? At first you used to come and dine with us two or three nights a week .

sp.speaker: GEORGE
sp.p: I can n't always be sponging on you . It 's positively indecent .

sp.speaker: DAISY
sp.p: We do n't know many people . It 's not always very lively here . I should have thought if you did n't care to come for my sake you 'd have come for Harry 's .

sp.speaker: GEORGE
sp.p: I come whenever you ask me .

sp.speaker: DAISY
sp.p: You have n't been here for a month .

sp.speaker: GEORGE
sp.p: It just happens that the last two or three times you 've asked me to dine I 've been engaged .

sp.speaker: DAISY
sp.p: Her voice breaking .You promised that we 'd be friends . What have I done to turn you against me ?

sp.speaker: GEORGE
sp.p: His armour pierced by the emotion in her voice .Oh , Daisy , do n't speak like that .

sp.speaker: DAISY
sp.p: I 've tried to do everything I could to please you . If there 's anything I do that you do n't like , wo n't you tell me ? I promise you I wo n't do it .

sp.speaker: GEORGE
sp.p: Oh , my dear child , you make me feel such an awful beast .

sp.speaker: DAISY
sp.p: Is it the past that you can n't forget ?

sp.speaker: GEORGE
sp.p: Good heavens , no , what do I care about the past ?

sp.speaker: DAISY
sp.p: I have so few friends . I 'm so awfully fond of you , George .

sp.speaker: GEORGE
sp.p: I do n't think I 've given you much cause to be that .

sp.speaker: DAISY
sp.p: There must be some reason why you wo n't ever come near me . Why wo n't you tell me ?

sp.speaker: GEORGE
sp.p: Oh , it 's absurd , you 're making a mountain out of a molehill .

sp.speaker: DAISY
sp.p: You used to be so jolly , and we used to laugh together . I looked forward so much to your coming here . What has changed you ?

sp.speaker: GEORGE
sp.p: Nothing has changed me .

sp.speaker: DAISY
sp.p: With a passion of despair .Oh , I might as well batter my head against a brick wall . How can you be so unkind to me ?

sp.speaker: GEORGE
sp.p: For God 's sake ...He stops .Heaven knows , I do n't want to be unkind to you .

sp.speaker: DAISY
sp.p: Then why do you treat me as an outcast ? Oh , it 's cruel , cruel .

div.stage: GEORGE is excessively distressed . He walks up and down , frowning . He cannot bear to look at DAISY and he speaks with hesitation .

sp.speaker: GEORGE
sp.p: You 'll think me an awful rotter , Daisy , but you can n't think me more of a rotter than I think myself . I do n't know how to say it . It seems such an awful thing to say . I 'm so ashamed of myself . I do n't suppose two men have ever been greater pals than Harry and I . He 's married to you and he 's awfully in love with you . And I think you 're in love with him . I was only twenty-three when I — first knew you . It 's an awful long time ago , is n't it ? There are some wounds that never quite heal , you know . Oh , my God , do n't you understand ?His embarrassment , the distraction of his tone , and the way the halting words fall unwillingly from his lips have betrayed the truth to DAISY . She does not speak , she does not stir , she looks at him with great shining eyes . She hardly dares to breathe .If ever you wanted revenge on me you 've got it now . You must see that it 's better that I should n't come here too often . Forgive me — Goodby .

div.stage: He hurries away with averted face . DAISY stands motionless , erect ; she is almost transfigured . She draws a long breath .

sp.speaker: DAISY
sp.p: Oh , God ! He loves me .

div.stage: She takes the orchids he has brought her and crushes them to her heart . The AMAH appears .

sp.speaker: AMAH
sp.p: You wantchee buy Manchu dress , Daisy ?

sp.speaker: DAISY
sp.p: Go away .

sp.speaker: AMAH
sp.p: Velly cheap . You look see . No likee , no buy .

sp.speaker: DAISY
sp.p: Impatiently .I 'm sick of curio-dealers .

sp.speaker: AMAH
sp.p: Velly pletty Manchu dresses .

div.stage: She draws aside a little and allows a man with a large bundle wrapped up in a blue cotton cloth to come in . He is a Chinese . He is dressed in a long black robe and a round black cap . It is LEE TAI CHENG . He is big and rather stout . From his smooth and yellow face his black eyes gleam craftily . He lays his bundle on the ground and unties it , showing a pile of gorgeous Manchu dresses . DAISY has taken no notice of him . Suddenly she sees that a man , with his back turned to her , is there .

sp.speaker: DAISY
sp.p: To the AMAH .I told you I would n't see the man . Send him away at once .

sp.speaker: LEE TAI
sp.p: Turning round , with a sly smile .You look see . No likee , no buy .

sp.speaker: DAISY
sp.p: With a start of surprise and dismay .Lee !

sp.speaker: LEE TAI
sp.p: Coming forward coolly .Good afternoon , Daisy .

sp.speaker: DAISY
sp.p: Recovering herself .It 's lucky for you I 'm in a good temper or I 'd have you thrown out by the boys . What have you brought this junk for ?

sp.speaker: LEE TAI
sp.p: A curio-dealer can come and go and no one wonders .

sp.speaker: AMAH
sp.p: Lee Tai velly clever man .

sp.speaker: DAISY
sp.p: Give me that chain .The AMAH takes it out of her sleeve and gives it to her . DAISY flings it contemptuously at LEE TAI 'S feet .Take it . Pack up your things and go . If you ever dare to show your face here again , I 'll tell my husband .

sp.speaker: LEE TAI
sp.p: With a chuckle .What will you tell him ? Do n't you be a silly girl , Daisy .

sp.speaker: DAISY
sp.p: What do you want ?

sp.speaker: LEE TAI
sp.p: Coolly .You .

sp.speaker: DAISY
sp.p: Do n't you know that I loathe you ? You disgust me .

sp.speaker: LEE TAI
sp.p: What do I care ? Perhaps if you loved me I should n't want you . Your hatred is like a sharp and bitter sauce that tickles my appetite .

sp.speaker: DAISY
sp.p: You beast .

sp.speaker: LEE TAI
sp.p: I like the horror that makes your body tremble when I hold you in my arms . And sometimes the horror turns on a sudden into a wild tempest of passion .

sp.speaker: DAISY
sp.p: You liar .

sp.speaker: LEE TAI
sp.p: Leave this stupid white man . What is he to you ?

sp.speaker: DAISY
sp.p: He is my husband .

sp.speaker: LEE TAI
sp.p: It is a year to-day since you were married . What has marriage done for you ? You thought when you married a white man you 'd become a white woman . Do you think they can look at you and forget ? How many white women do you know ? How many friends have you got ? You 're a prisoner . I 'll take you to Singapore or Calcutta . Do n't you want to amuse yourself ? Do you want to go to Europe ? I 'll take you to Paris . I 'll give you more money to spend in a week than your husband earns in a year .

sp.speaker: DAISY
sp.p: I 'm very comfortable in Peking , thank you .

sp.speaker: LEE TAI
sp.p: Snapping his fingers .You do n't care that for your husband . He loves you . You despise him . Do n't you wish with all your heart that you had n't married him ?

sp.speaker: AMAH
sp.p: He very silly white man . He no likee Daisy 's old amah . Perhaps one day he b'long sick . Daisy cry velly much if he die ?

sp.speaker: DAISY
sp.p: Impatiently .Do n't be such a fool .

sp.speaker: AMAH
sp.p: Perhaps one day he drink whisky soda . Oh , velly ill , velly ill. What 's the matter with me ? No sabe . No can stand . Doctor no sabe . Then die . Hi , hi .

sp.speaker: DAISY
sp.p: You silly old woman . Harry 's not a Chinaman and he would n't call in a Chinese doctor .

sp.speaker: LEE TAI
sp.p: With a smile .China is a very old and a highly civilized country , Daisy . When anyone is in your way , it 's not very difficult to get rid of him .

sp.speaker: DAISY
sp.p: Scornfully .And do you think I 'd let poor Harry be murdered so that I might be free to listen to your generous proposals ? You must think I 'm a fool if you expect me to risk my neck for that .

sp.speaker: LEE TAI
sp.p: You do n't take any risk , Daisy . You know nothing .

sp.speaker: AMAH
sp.p: Lee Tai velly clever man , Daisy .

sp.speaker: DAISY
sp.p: I thought so once . Lee Tai , you 're a damned fool . Get out .

sp.speaker: LEE TAI
sp.p: Freedom is a very good thing , Daisy .

sp.speaker: DAISY
sp.p: What should I do with it ?

sp.speaker: LEE TAI
sp.p: Would n't you like to be free now ?She looks at him sharply . She wonders if it can possibly be that he suspects her passion for George Conway . He meets her glance steadily .One day Sen Shi Ming was sitting with his wife looking at a Tang bronze that he had just bought when he heard someone in the street crying for help . Sen Shi was a very brave man and he snatched up a revolver and ran out . Sen Shi forgot that he had cheated his brother out of a house in Hatamen Street or he would have been more prudent . Sen Shi was found by the watchman an hour later with a dagger in his heart . Who killed cock-robin ?

sp.speaker: AMAH
sp.p: Hi , hi . Sen Shi velly silly man .

sp.speaker: LEE TAI
sp.p: His brother knew that . They had grown up together . If I heard cries for help outside my house late in the night , I should ask myself who had a grudge against me , and I should make sure the door was bolted . But white men are very brave . White men do n't know the Chinese customs . Would you be very sorry if an accident happened to your excellent husband ?

sp.speaker: DAISY
sp.p: I wonder what you take me for ?

sp.speaker: LEE TAI
sp.p: Why do you pretend to me , Daisy ? Do you think I do n't know you ?

sp.speaker: DAISY
sp.p: The door is a little on the left of you , Lee Tai . Would you give yourself the trouble of walking through it ?

sp.speaker: LEE TAI
sp.p: With a smile .I go , but I come back . Perhaps you 'll change your mind .

div.stage: He ties up his bundle and is about to go . HARRY enters .

sp.speaker: DAISY
sp.p: Oh , Harry , you 're back very soon !

sp.speaker: HARRY
sp.p: Yes , the pony went lame . Fortunately I had n't gone far before I noticed it . Who 's this ?

sp.speaker: DAISY
sp.p: It 's a curio-dealer . He has nothing I want . I was just sending him away .

div.stage: LEE TAI takes up his bundle and goes out .

sp.speaker: HARRY
sp.p: Noticing the orchids .Someone been sending you flowers ?

sp.speaker: DAISY
sp.p: George .

sp.speaker: HARRY
sp.p: Rather nice of him .To the AMAH .Run along , amah , I want to talk to missy .

sp.speaker: AMAH
sp.p: All light .

sp.speaker: HARRY
sp.p: And do n't let me catch you listening round the corner .

sp.speaker: AMAH
sp.p: My no listen . What for I listen ?

sp.speaker: HARRY
sp.p: Run along — chop-chop .

sp.speaker: AMAH
sp.p: Can do .She goes out .

sp.speaker: HARRY
sp.p: With a laugh .I could n't give you a greater proof of my affection than consenting to have that old woman around all the time .

sp.speaker: DAISY
sp.p: I do n't know why you dislike her . She 's devoted to me .

sp.speaker: HARRY
sp.p: That 's the only reason I put up with her . She gives me the creeps . I have the impression that she watches every movement I make .

sp.speaker: DAISY
sp.p: Oh , what nonsense !

sp.speaker: HARRY
sp.p: And I 've caught her eavesdropping .

sp.speaker: DAISY
sp.p: Was it amah that you wanted to talk to me about ?

lg.l: No , I 've got something to tell you . How would you like to leave
Peking ?

sp.speaker: DAISY
sp.p: With a start , suddenly off her guard .Not at all .

sp.speaker: HARRY
sp.p: I 'm afraid it 's awfully dull for you here , darling .

sp.speaker: DAISY
sp.p: I do n't find it so .

sp.speaker: HARRY
sp.p: You 're so dear and sweet . Are you sure you do n't say that on my account ?

sp.speaker: DAISY
sp.p: I 'm very fond of Peking .

sp.speaker: HARRY
sp.p: We 've been married a year now . I do n't want to hurt your feelings , darling , but it 's no good beating about the bush , and I think it 's better to be frank .

sp.speaker: DAISY
sp.p: Surely you can say anything you like to me without hesitation .

sp.speaker: HARRY
sp.p: Things have been a little awkward in a way . The women I used to know before we married left cards on you —

sp.speaker: DAISY
sp.p: Having taken the precaution to discover that I should be out .

sp.speaker: HARRY
sp.p: And you returned those cards and that was the end of it . I asked George what he thought about my taking you to the club to play tennis and he said he thought we 'd better not risk it . The result is that you do n't know a soul .

sp.speaker: DAISY
sp.p: Have I complained ?

sp.speaker: HARRY
sp.p: You 've been most awfully decent about it , but I hate to think of your spending day after day entirely by yourself . It can n't be good for you to be so much alone .

sp.speaker: DAISY
sp.p: I might have known Mrs. Chuan . She 's a white woman .

sp.speaker: HARRY
sp.p: Oh , my dear , she was — heaven knows what she was ! She 's married to a Chinaman . It 's horrible . She 's outside the pale .

lg.l: And there 's Bertha Raymond . She 's very nice , even though she is a
Eurasian .

sp.speaker: HARRY
sp.p: I 'm sure she 's very nice , but we could n't very well have the Raymonds here and refuse to go to them . Her brother is one of the clerks in my office . I do n't want to seem an awful snob ....

sp.speaker: DAISY
sp.p: You need n't hesitate to say anything about the Eurasians . You can n't hate and despise them more than I do .

sp.speaker: HARRY
sp.p: I do n't hate and despise them . I think that 's odious . But sometimes they 're not very tactful . I do n't know that I much want one of my clerks to come and slap me on the back in the office and call me old chap .

sp.speaker: DAISY
sp.p: Of course not .

sp.speaker: HARRY
sp.p: The fact is we 've been trying to do an impossible thing . It 's no good kicking against the pricks . What with the legations and one thing and another Peking 's hopeless . We 'd far better clear out .

sp.speaker: DAISY
sp.p: But if I do n't mind why should you ?

sp.speaker: HARRY
sp.p: Well , it 's not very nice for me either . It 's for my sake just as much as for yours that I 'd be glad to go elsewhere . Of course everybody at the club knows I 'm married . Some of them ignore it altogether . I do n't mind that so much . Some of them ask after you with an exaggerated cordiality which is rather offensive . And every now and then some fool begins to slang the Eurasians and everybody kicks him under the table . Then he remembers about me and goes scarlet . By God , it 's hell .

sp.speaker: DAISY
sp.p: Sulkily .I do n't want to leave Peking . I 'm very happy here .

sp.speaker: HARRY
sp.p: Well , darling , I 've applied for a transfer .

sp.speaker: DAISY
sp.p: With sudden indignation .Without saying a word to me ?

sp.speaker: HARRY
sp.p: I thought you 'd be glad . I did n't want to say anything till it was settled .

sp.speaker: DAISY
sp.p: Do you think I am a child to have everything arranged for me without a word ?Trying to control herself .After all , you 'd never see George . Surely you do n't want to lose sight of your only real friend .

sp.speaker: HARRY
sp.p: I 've talked it over with George and he thinks it 's the best thing to do .

sp.speaker: DAISY
sp.p: Did he advise you to go ?

sp.speaker: HARRY
sp.p: Strongly .

sp.speaker: DAISY
sp.p: Violently .I wo n't do it . I wo n't leave Peking .

sp.speaker: HARRY
sp.p: Why should his advice make the difference ?

sp.speaker: DAISY
sp.p: Why ?She is confused for a moment , but quickly recovers herself .I wo n't let George Conway — or anybody else — decide where I 'm to go .

sp.speaker: HARRY
sp.p: Do n't be unreasonable , darling .

sp.speaker: DAISY
sp.p: I wo n't go . I tell you I wo n't go .

sp.speaker: HARRY
sp.p: Well , I 'm afraid you must now . It 's all settled . The transfer is decided .

sp.speaker: DAISY
sp.p: Bursting into tears .Oh , Harry , do n't take me away from here . I can n't bear it . I want to stay here .

sp.speaker: HARRY
sp.p: Oh , darling , how can you be so silly ! You 'll have a much better time at one of the outports . You see , there are so few white people there that they can n't afford to put on frills . They 'll be jolly glad to know us both . We shall lead a normal life and be like everybody else .

sp.speaker: DAISY
sp.p: Sulkily .Where do you want to go ?

sp.speaker: HARRY
sp.p: I 've been put in charge of our place at Chung-king .

lg.l: Chung-king ! Of course you 'd choose
Chung-king .

sp.speaker: HARRY
sp.p: Why , what 's wrong with it ? Do you know it ?

sp.speaker: DAISY
sp.p: No — oh , what am I talking about ? I 'm all confused . Yes , I was there once when I was a girl . It 's a hateful place .

sp.speaker: HARRY
sp.p: Oh , nonsense ! The consul 's got a charming wife , and there are quite a nice lot of people there .

sp.speaker: DAISY
sp.p: Distracted .Oh , what shall I do ? I 'm so unhappy . If you cared for me at all you would n't treat me so cruelly . You 're ashamed of me . You want to hide me . Why should I bury myself in a hole two thousand miles up the river ? I wo n't go ! I wo n't go ! I wo n't go !She bursts into a storm of hysterical weeping .

sp.speaker: HARRY
sp.p: Trying to take her in his arms .Oh , Daisy , for God 's sake do n't cry . You know I 'm not ashamed of you . I love you more than ever . I love you with all my heart .

sp.speaker: DAISY
sp.p: Drawing away from him .Do n't touch me . Leave me alone . I hate you .

sp.speaker: HARRY
sp.p: Do n't say that , Daisy . It hurts me frightfully .

sp.speaker: DAISY
sp.p: Oh , go away , go away !

sp.speaker: HARRY
sp.p: Seeking to reason with her .I can n't leave you like this .

lg.l: Go , go , go , go , go ! I do n't want to see you ! Oh , God , what shall
I do ?

div.stage: She flings herself doom on the steps , weeping hysterically . HARRY , much distressed , looks at her in perplexity . The AMAH comes in .

sp.speaker: AMAH
sp.p: You make missy cly . You velly bad man .

sp.speaker: HARRY
sp.p: What the devil do you want ?

sp.speaker: AMAH
sp.p: Going up to DAISY and stroking her head .What thing he talkee my poor little flower ? Maskee . He belong velly bad man .

sp.speaker: HARRY
sp.p: Shut up , you old ... I wo n't have you talk like that . I 've put up with a good deal from you , but if you try to make mischief between Daisy and me , by God , I 'll throw you out into the street with my own hands .

sp.speaker: AMAH
sp.p: What thing you do my Daisy ? Do n't cly , Daisy .

sp.speaker: HARRY
sp.p: Darling , do n't be unreasonable .

sp.speaker: DAISY
sp.p: Go away , do n't come near me . I hate you .

sp.speaker: HARRY
sp.p: How can you say anything so unkind ?

sp.speaker: DAISY
sp.p: Send him away .She begins to sob again more violently .

sp.speaker: AMAH
sp.p: You go away . You no can see she no wanchee you . You come back bimeby . My sabe talk to little flower .

div.stage: HARRY hesitates for a moment . He is harassed by the scene . Then he makes up his mind the best thing is to leave DAISY with the AMAH . He goes out . DAISY raises her head cautiously .

sp.speaker: DAISY
sp.p: Has he gone ?

sp.speaker: AMAH
sp.p: Yes . He go drink whisky soda .

sp.speaker: DAISY
sp.p: Do you know what he wants ?

lg.l: What for he tell me no listen ? So fashion I sabe he say something
I wanchee hear . He wanchee you leave Peking .

sp.speaker: DAISY
sp.p: I wo n't go .

sp.speaker: AMAH
sp.p: Harry velly silly man . He alla same pig . You pull thisa way , he pull thata way . If Harry say you go from Peking — you go .

sp.speaker: DAISY
sp.p: Never , never , never !

sp.speaker: AMAH
sp.p: You go away from Peking you never see George anymore .

sp.speaker: DAISY
sp.p: I should die . Oh , I want him ! I want him to love me . I want him to hurt me . I want ....In her passion she has dug her hands hard into the AMAH .

sp.speaker: AMAH
sp.p: Pushing away DAISY 'S hands .Oh !

sp.speaker: DAISY
sp.p: He loves me . That 's the only thing that matters . All the rest ....

sp.speaker: AMAH
sp.p: Harry wanchee you go Chung-king . Missionary ladies like see you again , Daisy . Perhaps they ask you how you like living along Lee Tai Cheng . Perhaps somebody tell Harry .

sp.speaker: DAISY
sp.p: The fool . Of all the places in China he must hit upon Chung-king .

sp.speaker: AMAH
sp.p: You know Harry . If he say go Chung-king , he go . You cly , he velly solly , he all same go .

sp.speaker: DAISY
sp.p: Oh , I know his obstinacy . When he 's once made up his mind —Contemptuously .— he prides himself on his firmness . Oh , what shall I do ?

sp.speaker: AMAH
sp.p: I think more better something happen to Harry .

sp.speaker: DAISY
sp.p: No , no , no !

sp.speaker: AMAH
sp.p: What you flightened for ? You no do anything . I tell Lee Tai more better something happen to Harry . I say you not velly sorry if Harry die .

sp.speaker: DAISY
sp.p: Putting her hands over her ears .Be quiet ! I wo n't listen to you .

sp.speaker: AMAH
sp.p: Roughly tearing her hands away .Do n't you be such a big fool , Daisy . You go to Chung-king and Harry know everything . Maybe he kill you .

sp.speaker: DAISY
sp.p: What do I care ?

sp.speaker: AMAH
sp.p: You go to Chung-king , you never see George no more . George , he love my little Daisy . When Harry gone — George , he come say ....

sp.speaker: DAISY
sp.p: Oh , do n't tempt me , it 's horrible !

sp.speaker: AMAH
sp.p: He put his arms round you and you feel such a little small thing , you hear his heart beat quick , quick against your heart . And he throw back your head and he kiss you . And you think you die , little flower .

sp.speaker: DAISY
sp.p: Oh , I love him , I love him !

sp.speaker: AMAH
sp.p: Hi , hi .

sp.speaker: DAISY
sp.p: Thinking of the scene with George .He would hardly look at me and his hands were trembling . He was as white as a sheet .

sp.speaker: AMAH
sp.p: Persuasively .I tell you , Daisy . You no say yes , you no say no . I ask Buddha .

sp.speaker: DAISY
sp.p: Frightened .What for ?

sp.speaker: AMAH
sp.p: If Buddha say yes , I talk with Lee Tai ; if Buddha say no , I do nothing . Then you go to Chung-king and you never see George any more .

div.stage: The AMAH goes up the temple steps and flings open the great doors . DAISY watches her with an agony of horror , expectation , and dread . The AMAH lights some joss-sticks on the altar , and strikes a deep-toned gong . HARRY comes in , followed by LEE TAI with his bundle .

sp.speaker: HARRY
sp.p: Anxious to make his peace .Daisy , I found this fellow hanging about in the courtyard . I thought I 'd like to buy you a Manchu dress that he 's got .

sp.speaker: DAISY
sp.p: After a moment 's reflection , with a change of tone .That 's very nice of you , Harry .

sp.speaker: HARRY
sp.p: It 's a real beauty . You 'll look stunning in it .

sp.speaker: LEE TAI
sp.p: Showing the dress , speaking in Pidgin English .Firs class dless . He belong Manchu plincess . Manchus no got money . No got money , no can chow . Manchus sell velly cheap . You takee , Missy .

div.stage: DAISY and LEE TAI exchange glances . DAISY is grave and tragic , whereas LEE TAI has an ironical glint in his eyes . Meanwhile the AMAH has been bowing before the altar . She goes down on her knees and knocks her head on the ground .

sp.speaker: HARRY
sp.p: What in God 's Name is amah doing ?

sp.speaker: DAISY
sp.p: She 's asking Buddha a question .

sp.speaker: HARRY
sp.p: What question ?

sp.speaker: DAISY
sp.p: With a shadow of a smile .How should I know ?

sp.speaker: HARRY
sp.p: What 's the idea ?

sp.speaker: DAISY
sp.p: Have n't you ever seen the Chinese do it ? You see those pieces of wood she 's holding in her hands . She 's holding them out to the Buddha so that he may see them and she 's telling him that he must answer the question .Meanwhile the AMAH , muttering in a low tone , is seen doing what DAISY describes .The Buddha smells the incense of the burning joss-sticks , and he 's pleased and he listens to what she says .

sp.speaker: HARRY
sp.p: Smiling .Do n't be so absurd , Daisy . One might almost think you believed all this nonsense . Why , you 're quite pale .

sp.speaker: DAISY
sp.p: Then she gets up . The pieces of wood are flat on one side and round on the other . She 'll lift them above her head and she 'll drop them in front of the Buddha . If they fall with the round side uppermost it means yes .DAISY has been growing more and more excited as the ceremony proceeds . Now the AMAH steps back a little and she raises her arms . DAISY gives a shriek and starts to run forward .No ! no ! Stop !

sp.speaker: HARRY
sp.p: Instinctively seizing her arms .Daisy !

div.stage: At the same moment the AMAH has let the pieces of wood fall . She looks at them for an instant and then turns round .

sp.speaker: AMAH
sp.p: Buddha talkee , can do .

sp.speaker: DAISY
sp.p: To HARRY .Why did you stop me ?

sp.speaker: HARRY
sp.p: Daisy , how can you be so superstitious ? What is the result ?

sp.speaker: DAISY
sp.p: Amah asked Buddha a question and the answer is yes .She puts her hand to her heart for an instant , then looking at HARRY she smiles .I 'm sorry I was silly and unreasonable just now , Harry . END OF SCENE III

div.head: SCENE IV

stage.stage: The sitting-room in the ANDERSONS ’ apartments . At the back are two double doors . The lower part of them is solid , but above they are cut in an intricate trellis . The ceiling is raftered , painted red and decorated with dim , gold dragons ; the walls are whitewashed . On them hang Chinese pictures on rolls . Between the doors is a little image of the domestic god , and under it a tiny oil lamp is burning . The furniture is partly Chinese and partly European . There is an English writing-table , but the occasional tables , richly carved , are Chinese . There is a Chinese pallet-bed , covered with bamboo matting , and there is an English Chesterfield . There are a couple of Philippine rattan chairs and one or two of Cantonese blackwood . On the floor is a Chinese carpet . A Ming tile here and there gives a vivid note of colour . It is a summer night and the doors are wide open . Through them you see one of the courtyards of the temple .

The AMAH is seated in one of the blackwood chairs by the side of a table . She has her water-pipe . She puts a pinch of tobacco in and then going to the lamp under the image lights a taper . She seats herself again and lights her pipe . She smokes quietly .
DAISY comes in . She wears an evening dress somewhat too splendid for dinner with only her husband and a friend .

sp.speaker: AMAH . B . A. T
sp.p: fellow , when he go ?

sp.speaker: DAISY
sp.p: You know his name . Why do n't you call him by it ? I think he 's going almost at once .

sp.speaker: AMAH
sp.p: What for he go so soon ?

sp.speaker: DAISY
sp.p: That 's his business , is n't it ? As a matter of fact his sister is arriving from England , and he has to go to meet her .

sp.speaker: AMAH
sp.p: More better he go soon .

sp.speaker: DAISY
sp.p: Why do you smoke your pipe here ? You know Harry does n't like it .

sp.speaker: AMAH
sp.p: Harry one big fool , I think . When you go to Chung-king ?

sp.speaker: DAISY
sp.p: Harry has n't said a word about it since .

sp.speaker: AMAH
sp.p: You got key that desk ?

sp.speaker: DAISY
sp.p: No . Harry keeps all his private papers there .

div.stage: The AMAH goes up to the desk and tries one of the drawers . It is locked and she cannot open it .

sp.speaker: AMAH
sp.p: What Harry do now ?

sp.speaker: DAISY
sp.p: He and Mr. Knox are drinking their port .

div.stage: The AMAH takes out a skeleton key out of her pocket and inserts it in the lock . She turns the key .

sp.speaker: AMAH
sp.p: Velly bad lock . I think him made in Germany . Hi , hi .She opens the drawer and takes out a revolver . She hands it to DAISY .Lee Tai say , you take out cartridges .

sp.speaker: DAISY
sp.p: What do you mean ?She suddenly guesses the truth and gives a cry .Oh !

sp.speaker: AMAH
sp.p: Hurriedly putting her hand over DAISY 'S mouth .Sh , you no make noise .Holding out the revolver .Lee Tai say , more better you do it .

sp.speaker: DAISY
sp.p: Take it away . No , no , I wo n't , I wo n't .

sp.speaker: AMAH
sp.p: Sh , sh . I do it . I sabe .

div.stage: She takes the cartridges out of the revolver and hides them about her . DAISY looks at her with horror .

sp.speaker: DAISY
sp.p: It 's not for to-night ?

sp.speaker: AMAH
sp.p: I no sabe .

sp.speaker: DAISY
sp.p: I wo n't have it . Do you hear ? Oh , I shall go mad !

sp.speaker: AMAH
sp.p: Then Harry shut you up . Hi , hi . All same Chung-king .

div.stage: She puts the revolver back into the drawer and shuts it just as HARRY and HAROLD KNOX come in . They wear dinner jackets .

sp.speaker: KNOX
sp.p: Hulloa , there 's the little ray of sunshine . I missed your bonny face before dinner .

sp.speaker: AMAH
sp.p: You velly funny man .

sp.speaker: KNOX
sp.p: No wonder I dote upon you , dearie . You 're the only attractive woman I 've ever been able to persuade that I was a humourist .

sp.speaker: HARRY
sp.p: Catching sight of the AMAH 'S water-pipe .I told you I would n't have your disgusting pipe in here , amah .

sp.speaker: AMAH
sp.p: Belong velly nice pipe .

sp.speaker: HARRY
sp.p: I swore I 'd throw the damned thing out myself if I found it lying about .

sp.speaker: AMAH
sp.p: Snatching it away .You no touch my pipe . You velly bad man . Velly bad temper . You no Christian .

sp.speaker: HARRY
sp.p: A fat lot you know about Christianity .

sp.speaker: AMAH
sp.p: I know plentything about Christianity . My father velly poor man . He say , you go and be Christian . I go Catholic mission and they baptize me . English Church missionary , he come along and say , Catholic mission no good , you go to hell , I baptize you . All right I say , you baptize me . By and by Baptist missionary come along and say , English Church mission no good , you go to hell , I baptize you . All right , I say , you baptize me . By and by Presbyterian missionary come along and say , Baptist mission no good , you go to hell , I baptize you . All right , I say , you baptize me .To KNOX .You know Seventh Day Adventists ?

sp.speaker: KNOX
sp.p: I 've heard of them .

lg.l: By and by Seventh Day Adventist he come along and say ,
Presbyterian mission no good .

sp.speaker: KNOX
sp.p: You go to hell .

sp.speaker: AMAH
sp.p: How fashion you sabe what he said ?

sp.speaker: KNOX
sp.p: I guessed it .

sp.speaker: AMAH
sp.p: You go to hell , he say . I baptize you . I been baptized one , two , three , four , five times . I velly Christian woman .

sp.speaker: HARRY
sp.p: Smiling .I apologize .

sp.speaker: AMAH
sp.p: They all say to poor Chinese , love one another . I no think missionaries love one another velly much . Hi , hi .

sp.speaker: KNOX
sp.p: Taking out his watch .D'you mind if I look at the time ? I do n't want to get to the station late .

sp.speaker: HARRY
sp.p: Of course not . I say , wo n't you have a cigar ?He goes to his desk .I have to keep them locked up . I think the boys find them very much to their taste .He puts the key into the lock .Hulloa , the drawer 's open . I could have sworn I locked it .He takes out a box of cigars and hands it to KNOX .

sp.speaker: KNOX
sp.p: Helping himself .Thanks very much .

sp.speaker: DAISY
sp.p: You know , you must n't let me keep you if you want to be off .

sp.speaker: KNOX
sp.p: I 've got two or three minutes .

sp.speaker: HARRY
sp.p: Oh , Daisy , before Harold goes I wish you 'd show him that Manchu dress I bought you .

sp.speaker: DAISY
sp.p: I 'll go and fetch it .To the AMAH .Is it hanging up in the cupboard ?

sp.speaker: AMAH
sp.p: No , I have puttee in paper . I velly careful woman .

div.stage: They both go out .

sp.speaker: KNOX
sp.p: I say , old man , I hope you do n't think I 'm an awful swine to rush off like this the moment I 've swallowed my dinner .

sp.speaker: HARRY
sp.p: Rather not . As a matter of fact it 's not exactly inconvenient , because I 'm expecting George . I want him to have a heart to heart talk with Daisy .

sp.speaker: KNOX
sp.p: Oh .

sp.speaker: HARRY
sp.p: She 's grousing rather about going to Chung-king and I want him to tell her it 's a very decent place . He was vice-consul up there once . He 's dining at the Carmichael 's , but he said he 'd come along here as soon as he could get away .

sp.speaker: KNOX
sp.p: Then it 's all for the best in the best of all possible worlds .

div.stage: DAISY comes in with the dress .
