sp.speaker: DAISY
sp.p: Here it is .

sp.speaker: KNOX
sp.p: By George , is n't it stunning ? I must try to get one for my sister . She 'd simply go off her head if she saw that .

sp.speaker: DAISY
sp.p: Harry spoils me , does n't he ?

sp.speaker: KNOX
sp.p: Harry 's a very lucky young fellow to have you to spoil .

sp.speaker: DAISY
sp.p: Smiling .Go away or you 'll never arrive in time .

sp.speaker: KNOX
sp.p: I 'm off . Goodby and thanks very much . Dinner was top-hole .

sp.speaker: DAISY
sp.p: Goodby .

div.stage: He goes out . HARRY accompanies him into the courtyard and for a moment is lost to view . The gaiety on DAISY 'S face vanishes and a look of anxiety takes its place .

sp.speaker: DAISY
sp.p: Calling hurriedly .Amah , amah .

sp.speaker: AMAH
sp.p: Coming in .What thing ?

sp.speaker: DAISY
sp.p: What have you done ? Have you ...?She stops , unable to complete the agonised question .

sp.speaker: AMAH
sp.p: What you talk about ? I done nothing . I only have joke with you . Hi , hi .

sp.speaker: DAISY
sp.p: Will you swear that 's true ?

sp.speaker: AMAH
sp.p: Never tell a lie . Velly good Christian .

div.stage: DAISY looks at her searchingly . She does not know whether to believe or not . HARRY returns .

sp.speaker: HARRY
sp.p: I say , Daisy , I wish you 'd put on the dress . I 'd love to see how you look in it .

sp.speaker: DAISY
sp.p: With a smile .Shall I ?

sp.speaker: HARRY
sp.p: Amah will help you . It 'll suit you right down to the ground .

sp.speaker: DAISY
sp.p: Wait a minute . Bring the dress along , amah .

sp.speaker: AMAH
sp.p: All right .

div.stage: DAISY goes out , followed by the AMAH with the Manchu dress . HARRY goes to his desk and opens the drawer . He examines the lock and looks at the keyhole .

sp.speaker: HARRY
sp.p: To himself .I wonder if that old devil 's got a key .

div.stage: He shuts the drawer , but does not lock it . He strolls back to the middle of the room .

sp.speaker: DAISY
sp.p: In the adjoining room .Are you getting impatient ?

sp.speaker: HARRY
sp.p: Not a bit .

sp.speaker: DAISY
sp.p: I 'm just ready .

sp.speaker: HARRY
sp.p: I 'm holding my breath .DAISY comes in . She is in full Manchu dress . She is strangely changed . There is nothing European about her any more . She is mysterious and enigmatical .Daisy !She gives him a little smile but does not answer . She stands quite still for him to look at her .By George , how Chinese you look !

sp.speaker: DAISY
sp.p: Do n't you like it ?

sp.speaker: HARRY
sp.p: I do n't know . You 've just knocked me off my feet . Like it ? You 're wonderful . In my wildest dreams I never saw you like that . You 've brought all the East into the room with you . My head reels as though I were drunk .

sp.speaker: DAISY
sp.p: It 's strange that I feel as if these things were made for me . They make me feel so different .

sp.speaker: HARRY
sp.p: I thought that no one in the world was more normal than I. I 'm ashamed of myself . You 're almost a stranger to me and by God , I feel as though the marrow of my bones were melting . I hear the East a-calling . I have such a pain in my heart . Oh , my pretty , my precious , I love you .

div.stage: He falls down on his knees before her and clasps both his arms round her .

sp.speaker: DAISY
sp.p: In a low voice , hardly her own .Why , Harry , what are you talking about ?

div.stage: She caresses his hair with her long , delicate Chinese hand .

sp.speaker: HARRY
sp.p: I 'm such a fool . My heart is full of wonderful thoughts and I can only say that — that I worship the very ground you walk on .

sp.speaker: DAISY
sp.p: Do n't kneel , Harry ; that is n't the way a woman wants to be loved .

div.stage: She raises him to his feet and as he rises he takes her in his arms .

sp.speaker: HARRY
sp.p: Passionately .I 'd do anything in the world for you .

sp.speaker: DAISY
sp.p: You could make me so happy if you chose .

sp.speaker: HARRY
sp.p: I do choose .

sp.speaker: DAISY
sp.p: Wo n't you give up this idea of leaving Peking ?

sp.speaker: HARRY
sp.p: But , my darling , it 's for your happiness I 'm doing it .

sp.speaker: DAISY
sp.p: Do n't you think that everyone is the best judge of his own happiness ?

sp.speaker: HARRY
sp.p: Not always .

sp.speaker: DAISY
sp.p: Disengaging herself from his arms .Ah , that 's the English way . You want to make people happy in your way and not in theirs . You 'll never be satisfied till the Chinese wear Norfolk jackets and eat roast beef and plum pudding .

sp.speaker: HARRY
sp.p: Oh , my dear , do n't let 's argue now .

sp.speaker: DAISY
sp.p: You say you 'll give me everything in the world and you wo n't give me the one thing I want . What 's the good of offering me the moon if I have a nail in my shoe and you wo n't take it out ?

sp.speaker: HARRY
sp.p: Well , you can smile , so it 's not very serious , is it ?

sp.speaker: DAISY
sp.p: Putting her arms round his neck .Oh , Harry , I 'll love you so much if you 'll only do what I ask . You do n't know me yet . Oh , Harry !

sp.speaker: HARRY
sp.p: My darling , I love you with all my heart and soul , but when I 've once made up my mind nothing on earth is going to make me change it . We can only be happy and natural if we go . You must submit to my judgment .

sp.speaker: DAISY
sp.p: How can you be so obstinate ?

sp.speaker: HARRY
sp.p: My dear , look at yourself in the glass now .

div.stage: She looks down on her Manchu dress . She understands what he means . She is a Chinese woman .

sp.speaker: DAISY
sp.p: With a change of tone .Amah , bring me a tea-gown .

div.stage: She begins to undo the long Manchu coat . The AMAH comes in with a tea-gown .

sp.speaker: HARRY
sp.p: Dryly .It 's very convenient that you should always be within earshot when you 're wanted , amah .

sp.speaker: AMAH
sp.p: I velly good amah . Velly Christian woman .

div.stage: DAISY slips off the Manchu clothes and is helped by the AMAH into the tea-gown . She wraps it round her . She is once more a white woman .

lg.l: Take those things away .
Would you like to have a game of chess ?

sp.speaker: HARRY
sp.p: Very much . I 'll get the men .

div.stage: DAISY goes to the gramophone and turns on a Chinese tune . It is strange and exotic . Its monotony exacerbates the nerves . HARRY gets the chessboard and sets up the pieces . They sit down opposite one another . The AMAH has disappeared with the discarded dress .

sp.speaker: HARRY
sp.p: Will you take white ?

sp.speaker: DAISY
sp.p: If you like .She moves a piece .

sp.speaker: HARRY
sp.p: I hate your queen opening . It always flummoxes me . I do n't know where you learned to play so well . I never have a chance against you .

sp.speaker: DAISY
sp.p: I was taught by a Chinaman . It 's a game they take to naturally .

div.stage: They make two or three moves without a word . Suddenly , breaking across the silence , stridently , there is a shriek outside in the street . DAISY gives a little gasp .

sp.speaker: HARRY
sp.p: Hulloa , what 's that ?

sp.speaker: DAISY
sp.p: Oh , it 's nothing . It 's only some Chinese quarrelling .

div.stage: Two or three shouts are heard and then an agonised cry of “ Help , help . ” HARRY springs to his feet .

sp.speaker: HARRY
sp.p: By God , that 's English .

div.stage: He is just going to rush out when Daisy seizes his arm .

sp.speaker: DAISY
sp.p: What are you going to do ? No , no , do n't leave me , Harry .

div.stage: She clings to him . He pushes her away violently .

sp.speaker: HARRY
sp.p: Shut up . Do n't be a fool .

div.stage: He runs to the drawer of his desk . The cry is repeated : “ For God 's sake , help , help , oh ! ”

sp.speaker: HARRY
sp.p: My God , they 're killing someone . It can n't be ...He remembers that George is coming that evening .

sp.speaker: DAISY
sp.p: Throwing herself on him .No , Harry , do n't go , do n't go , I wo n't let you .

sp.speaker: HARRY
sp.p: Get out of my way .

div.stage: He pushes her violently aside and runs out . DAISY sinks to the floor and buries her face in her hands .

sp.speaker: DAISY
sp.p: Oh , my God !

div.stage: The AMAH has been waiting just outside one of the doors , in the courtyard , and now she slips in .

sp.speaker: AMAH
sp.p: Harry velly blave man . He hear white man being murdered . He run and help . Hi , hi .

sp.speaker: DAISY
sp.p: Oh , I can n't . Harry , Harry .

div.stage: She springs to her feet and runs towards the courtyard , with some instinctive idea of going to her husband 's help . The AMAH stops her .

sp.speaker: AMAH
sp.p: What side you go ?

sp.speaker: DAISY
sp.p: I can n't stand here and let Harry be murdered .

sp.speaker: AMAH
sp.p: You stop here .

sp.speaker: DAISY
sp.p: Let me go . For God 's sake let me go . Wu , Wu .

div.stage: The AMAH puts her hand over DAISY 'S mouth .

sp.speaker: AMAH
sp.p: You be quiet . You wanchee go prison ?

sp.speaker: DAISY
sp.p: Snatching away her hand .I 'll give you anything in the world if you 'll only let me go .

sp.speaker: AMAH
sp.p: You silly little fool , Daisy .

div.stage: DAISY struggles to release herself , but she is helpless in the AMAH 'S grasp .

sp.speaker: DAISY
sp.p: In an agony .It 'll be too late .

sp.speaker: AMAH
sp.p: Too late now . You no can help him .

div.stage: She releases DAISY . DAISY staggers forward and covers her face with her hands .

sp.speaker: DAISY
sp.p: Oh , what have I done ?

sp.speaker: AMAH
sp.p: With a snigger .You no done nothing , you know nothing .

sp.speaker: DAISY
sp.p: Violently .Curse you ! It 's you , you , you !

sp.speaker: AMAH
sp.p: I velly wicked woman . Curse me . Do me no harm .

sp.speaker: DAISY
sp.p: I told you I would n't have anything done to Harry .

sp.speaker: AMAH
sp.p: You say no with your lips but in your belly you say yes .

sp.speaker: DAISY
sp.p: No , no , no !

sp.speaker: AMAH
sp.p: You just big damned fool , Daisy . You no love Harry . Him not velly rich . Not velly big man . No good . You velly glad you finish with him .

sp.speaker: DAISY
sp.p: But not that way . He never did me any harm . He was always good to me and kind to me .

sp.speaker: AMAH
sp.p: That velly good way . Velly safe way .

sp.speaker: DAISY
sp.p: You devil ! I hate the sight of you .

sp.speaker: AMAH
sp.p: What for you hate me ? I do what you want . Your father velly clever man . He say : no break eggs , no can eat omelette .

sp.speaker: DAISY
sp.p: I wish I 'd never been born .

sp.speaker: AMAH
sp.p: Impatiently .What for you tell me lies ? You want Harry dead . Well , I kill him for you .With a sudden gust of anger .You no curse me or I beat you . You velly bad girl .

sp.speaker: DAISY
sp.p: Giving way .Oh , I feel so awfully faint !

sp.speaker: AMAH
sp.p: Tenderly , as though DAISY were still a child .You sit down . You take smelly salts .She helps DAISY into a chair and holds smelling salts to her nostrils .You feel better in a minute . Amah love her little Daisy flower . Harry him die and Daisy velly sorry . She cry and cry and cry . George velly sorry for Daisy . By and by Daisy no cry any more . She say , more better Harry dead . Good old amah , she do everything for little Daisy .

div.stage: DAISY has been looking at her with terrified eyes .

sp.speaker: DAISY
sp.p: What a brute I am ! I 'd give anything in the world to have Harry back , and yet in the bottom of my heart there 's a feeling — if I were free there 'd be nothing to stand between George and me .

sp.speaker: AMAH
sp.p: I think George he marry you maybe .

sp.speaker: DAISY
sp.p: Oh , not now ! It 'll bring me bad joss .

sp.speaker: AMAH
sp.p: You no wanchee fear , my little flower . You sit still or you feel bad again .

sp.speaker: DAISY
sp.p: Jumping up .How can I sit still ? The suspense is awful . Oh , my God , what 's happened ?

sp.speaker: AMAH
sp.p: With a cunning smile .I tell you what 's happened . Harry run outside and he see two , three men makee fighting . They a little way off . One man cry , “ Help , help ! ” Harry give shout and run . He fall down and him not get up again .

sp.speaker: DAISY
sp.p: He 's as strong as a horse . With his bare hands he 's a match for ten Chinamen .

sp.speaker: AMAH
sp.p: Lee Tai velly clever man . He no take risks . I think all finish now .

sp.speaker: DAISY
sp.p: Then for God 's sake let me go .

sp.speaker: AMAH
sp.p: More better you stay here , Daisy . Perhaps you get into trouble if you go out . They ask you why you go out ,— why you think something happen to your husband .

sp.speaker: DAISY
sp.p: I can n't let him lie there .

sp.speaker: AMAH
sp.p: He no lie velly long . By and by night watchman come here , and he say white man in the street — him dead . I think his throat cut .

sp.speaker: DAISY
sp.p: Oh , how horrible ! Harry , Harry !

div.stage: She buries her face in her hands .

sp.speaker: AMAH
sp.p: I light joss-stick . Make everything come all right .

div.stage: She goes over to the household image and lights a joss-stick in front of it . She bows before it and going on her knees knocks her head on the ground .

sp.speaker: DAISY
sp.p: How long is it going on ? How long have I got to wait ? Oh , what have I done ? The silence is awful .There is a silence . Suddenly DAISY breaks out into a shriek .No , no , no ! I wo n't have it . I can n't bear it . Oh , God help me !In the distance of the next courtyard is heard the chanting of the monks at the evening service . The AMAH , having finished her devotions , stands at the doorway looking out steadily . DAISY stares straight in front of her . Suddenly there is a loud booming of a gong . DAISY starts up .What 's that ?

sp.speaker: AMAH
sp.p: Be quiet , Daisy . Be careful .

div.stage: The door of the courtyard is flung open . HARRY comes in , through the courtyard , into the room , pushing before him a coolie whom he holds by the wrists and by the scruff of the neck .

sp.speaker: DAISY
sp.p: Harry !

sp.speaker: HARRY
sp.p: I 've got one of the blighters .Shouting .Here , bring me a rope .

sp.speaker: DAISY
sp.p: What 's happened ?

sp.speaker: HARRY
sp.p: Wait a minute . Thank God , I got there when I did .WU brings a rope and HARRY ties the man 's wrists behind his back .Keep quiet , you devil , or I 'll break your ruddy neck .He slips the rope through the great iron ring of one of the doors and ties it so that the man cannot get away .He 'll be all right there for the present . I 'll just go and telephone to the police station . Wu , you stand outside there . You watch him . Sabe ?

sp.speaker: WU
sp.p: I sabe .

div.stage: As HARRY goes out a crowd of people surge through the great open doorway of the courtyard . They are monks of the temple , attracted to the street by the quick rumour of accident , coolies , and the night watchman with his rattle . Some of them bear Chinese lanterns , some hurricane lamps . The crowd separates out as they approach the room and then it is seen that three men are bearing what seems to be the body of a man .

sp.speaker: DAISY
sp.p: What 's that ?

sp.speaker: AMAH
sp.p: I think belong foreign man .The men bring in the body and lay it on the sofa . The head and part of the chest are covered with a piece of blue cotton . DAISY and the AMAH look at it with dismay . They dare not approach . The ABBOT drives the crowd out of the room and shuts the doors , only leaving that side of one open at which the prisoner is attached . The AMAH turns on the god in the niche .You say can do . What for you make mistake ?

div.stage: She seizes a fan which is on the table under her hand and with angry violence hits the image on the face two or three times . DAISY has been staring at the body . She goes up to it softly and lifts the cloth slightly , she gives a start , and with a quick gesture snatches it away . She sees George Conway .

sp.speaker: DAISY
sp.p: George .She opens her mouth to shriek .

sp.speaker: AMAH
sp.p: Sh , take care . Harry hear .

sp.speaker: DAISY
sp.p: What have you done ?

sp.speaker: AMAH
sp.p: I do nothing . Buddha , he makee mistake .

sp.speaker: DAISY
sp.p: You fiend !

sp.speaker: AMAH
sp.p: How do I know , Daisy ? I no can tell George coming here to-night .The words come gurgling out , for DAISY has sprung upon her and seized her by the throat .Oh , let me go .

sp.speaker: DAISY
sp.p: You fiend .

div.stage: HARRY comes in . He is astounded at what he sees .

sp.speaker: HARRY
sp.p: Daisy , Daisy . What in God 's name are you doing ?

div.stage: Restrained by his voice , DAISY releases her hold of the AMAH , but violently , pushing her so that she falls to the ground . She lies there , putting her hand to her throat . DAISY turns to HARRY .

sp.speaker: DAISY
sp.p: It 's George .

lg.stage: Going up to the sofa and putting his hand on George 's heart .
lg.l: Confound it , I know it 's George .

sp.speaker: DAISY
sp.p: Is he dead ?

sp.speaker: HARRY
sp.p: No , he 's only had a bang on the head . He 's stunned . I 've sent for the doctor . Luckily he was dining at the Carmichaels ’ and I sent George 's rickshaw to bring him along as quick as he could come .

sp.speaker: DAISY
sp.p: Supposing he 's gone ?

sp.speaker: HARRY
sp.p: He wo n't have gone . They were going to play poker . By God , what 's this ?He takes away his hand and sees blood upon it .He 's been wounded . He 's bleeding .

div.stage: DAISY goes up to the body and kneeling down , feels the pulse .

sp.speaker: DAISY
sp.p: Are you sure he 's alive ?

sp.speaker: HARRY
sp.p: Yes , his heart 's beating all right . I wish the doctor would make haste . I do n't know what one ought to do .

sp.speaker: DAISY
sp.p: How do you know he 's at the Carmichaels ’ ?

sp.speaker: HARRY
sp.p: George told me yesterday he was going to be there . George said he did not want to play poker and he 'd come along here after dinner .

sp.speaker: DAISY
sp.p: Springing to her feet .Did you know George was coming ?

sp.speaker: HARRY
sp.p: Of course I did . When I heard someone shouting in English the first thing I thought of was George .

div.stage: DAISY bursts into a scream of hysterical laughter . The AMAH suddenly looks up and becomes attentive .

sp.speaker: HARRY
sp.p: Daisy , what 's the matter ?

lg.stage: Sliding to her feet and going up to Daisy , trying to stop her .
lg.l: Maskee . She only laughy laughy . You no trouble .

sp.speaker: HARRY
sp.p: Get some water or something .

sp.speaker: AMAH
sp.p: Frightened .Now , my pletty , my pletty .

sp.speaker: DAISY
sp.p: Recovering herself , violently .Let me be .

sp.speaker: HARRY
sp.p: By George , I believe he 's coming to . Bring the water here .

div.stage: DAISY takes the glass and leaning over the sofa , moistens GEORGE 'S lips . He slowly opens his eyes .

sp.speaker: GEORGE
sp.p: Funny stuff . What is it ?

lg.stage: With a chuckle that is half a sob .
lg.l: Do n't be a fool . Oh ,
George , you have given me a nasty turn .

sp.speaker: GEORGE
sp.p: There 's something the matter with the water .

sp.speaker: DAISY
sp.p: Looking at it quickly .What ?

sp.speaker: GEORGE
sp.p: Damn it all , there 's no brandy in it .

sp.speaker: DAISY
sp.p: If you make a joke I shall cry .

div.stage: He tries to move , but suddenly gives a groan .

sp.speaker: GEORGE
sp.p: Oh Lord . I 've got such a pain in my side .

sp.speaker: HARRY
sp.p: Keep quiet . The doctor will be here in a minute .

sp.speaker: GEORGE
sp.p: What is it ?

sp.speaker: HARRY
sp.p: I do n't know . There 's a lot of blood .

sp.speaker: GEORGE
sp.p: I hope I have n't made a mess on your nice new sofa .

sp.speaker: HARRY
sp.p: Damn the sofa . It 's lucky I heard you shout .

sp.speaker: GEORGE
sp.p: I never shouted .

sp.speaker: HARRY
sp.p: Oh , nonsense , I heard you . I thought it was you at once .

sp.speaker: GEORGE
sp.p: I heard a cry for help too . I was just coming along . I nipped out of my rickshaw and sprinted like hell . I saw some fellows struggling . I think someone hit me on the head . I do n't remember much .

sp.speaker: HARRY
sp.p: Who did cry for help ?

sp.speaker: GEORGE
sp.p: After a pause .Nobody .

sp.speaker: HARRY
sp.p: But I heard it . Daisy heard it too . It sounded like someone being murdered .As GEORGE gives a little chuckle .What 's the joke ?

sp.speaker: GEORGE
sp.p: Someone 's got his knife into you , old man , and the silly ass stuck it into me instead .

div.stage: The AMAH pricks up her ears .

sp.speaker: DAISY
sp.p: I 'm sure you ought n't to talk so much .

sp.speaker: GEORGE
sp.p: It 's a very old Chinese trick . They just got the wrong man , that 's all .

sp.speaker: HARRY
sp.p: By George , that explains why I tripped .

sp.speaker: GEORGE
sp.p: Did you trip ? A piece of string across the street .

sp.speaker: HARRY
sp.p: I was n't expecting it . I went down like a ninepin . I was up again in a flash and just threw myself at the blighters . You should have seen ‘ em scatter . Luckily I got one of them .

sp.speaker: GEORGE
sp.p: Good . Where is he ?

sp.speaker: HARRY
sp.p: He 's here . I 've tied him up pretty tight .

sp.speaker: GEORGE
sp.p: Well , we shall find out who 's at the bottom of this . The methods of the Chinese police may be uncivilized , but they are ... Oh , Lord , I do feel rotten .

sp.speaker: HARRY
sp.p: Oh , George .

div.stage: DAISY gives HARRY the glass and he helps GEORGE to drink .

sp.speaker: GEORGE
sp.p: That 's better .

sp.speaker: HARRY
sp.p: We 'd better get you to bed , old man .

sp.speaker: GEORGE
sp.p: All right .

sp.speaker: HARRY
sp.p: Wu and I will carry you . Wu , come along here .

div.stage: The boy approaches . The AMAH realizes that for a moment the prisoner is to be left unguarded . There is a table knife on one of the occasional tables with which DAISY has been cutting a book . The AMAH 'S hand closes over it .

sp.speaker: GEORGE
sp.p: Oh , no , that 's all right . I can walk .

div.stage: He gets up from the sofa . HARRY gives him an arm . He staggers .

lg.l: Wu , you fool .
No , let me take him ,
Daisy . You 're not strong enough .

sp.speaker: GEORGE
sp.p: Gasping .Sorry to make such an ass of myself .

div.stage: HARRY and WU , holding him one on each side , help him out of the room .

sp.speaker: DAISY
sp.p: Shall I come ?

sp.speaker: HARRY
sp.p: Oh , I 'll call you if you 're wanted .

div.stage: DAISY sinks into a chair , shuddering , and covers her face with her hands . The AMAH seizes her opportunity . She cuts the rope which binds the prisoner . As soon as he is free he steps out into the darkness . The AMAH watches for a moment and then cries out .

sp.speaker: AMAH
sp.p: Help , help !

div.stage: DAISY springs up and HARRY hurries in .

sp.speaker: HARRY
sp.p: What 's the matter ?

sp.speaker: AMAH
sp.p: Coolie . Him run away .

sp.speaker: HARRY
sp.p: Looking at the place where he had been tied up .By God !

sp.speaker: AMAH
sp.p: Missy feel velly ill. No can stand blood . Feel faint . I run fetch smelly salts and when I come back him gone . Him bad man .

div.stage: HARRY goes to the door and looks at the rope .

sp.speaker: HARRY
sp.p: This rope 's been cut .

sp.speaker: AMAH
sp.p: Perhaps he have knife . Why you no look see before you tie him .

sp.speaker: HARRY
sp.p: Looking at her sternly .How do you think he could get at a knife with his hands tied behind his back ?

sp.speaker: AMAH
sp.p: I no sabe . Maybe he have friend .

sp.speaker: HARRY
sp.p: Did n't you hear anything , Daisy ?

sp.speaker: DAISY
sp.p: No . I was n't thinking about him . Oh , Harry , George is n't going to die , is he ?

sp.speaker: HARRY
sp.p: I hope not . I do n't know what sort of a wound he 's got .The AMAH , thinking attention is withdrawn from her , is slipping away .No , you do n't . You stop here .

sp.speaker: AMAH
sp.p: What thing you wantchee ?

sp.speaker: HARRY
sp.p: You let that man go .

sp.speaker: AMAH
sp.p: You velly silly man . What for I want let him go ?

sp.speaker: HARRY
sp.p: Pointing .What 's that knife doing there ? That 's one of our knives .

sp.speaker: AMAH
sp.p: Missy takey knife cutty book .

sp.speaker: HARRY
sp.p: When I got into the street I wanted to fire my revolver to frighten them . There was n't a cartridge in it . I always keep it loaded and locked up .

sp.speaker: AMAH
sp.p: Revolver . I do n't know him . I never have see revolver . Never . Never .

div.stage: She makes a movement as though to go away . He seizes her wrist .

sp.speaker: HARRY
sp.p: Stop .

sp.speaker: AMAH
sp.p: My go chow . My belong velly hungly . You talk by and by .

sp.speaker: HARRY
sp.p: If I had n't come in just now , Daisy would have strangled you .

sp.speaker: AMAH
sp.p: Daisy velly excited . She no sabe what she do . She never hurt old amah .

sp.speaker: HARRY
sp.p: Why were you angry with her , Daisy ?

sp.speaker: DAISY
sp.p: Frightened .I was beside myself . I do n't know what I was doing .

sp.speaker: HARRY
sp.p: With sudden suspicion .Are you trying to shield her ?

sp.speaker: DAISY
sp.p: Of course not . Why on earth should I do that ?

sp.speaker: HARRY
sp.p: I suppose you look on it as a matter of no importance that she tried to kill me .

sp.speaker: DAISY
sp.p: Oh , Harry , how can you say anything so cruel ? Why should she try and kill you ?

sp.speaker: HARRY
sp.p: I do n't know . How do you expect me to guess what is at the back of a Chinese brain ? She 's hated me always .

sp.speaker: AMAH
sp.p: You no love me velly much .

sp.speaker: HARRY
sp.p: I 've put up with her just because she was attached to you . I knew she was a liar and a thief . It was a trap and I escaped by a miracle . Only , George has got to suffer for it .

sp.speaker: DAISY
sp.p: Harry , you 're nervous and excited .

sp.speaker: HARRY
sp.p: What are you defending her for ?

sp.speaker: DAISY
sp.p: I 'm not defending her .

sp.speaker: HARRY
sp.p: One would almost think she had some hold on you . I 've never seen anyone let an amah behave as you let her behave .

sp.speaker: DAISY
sp.p: She 's been with me since I was a child . She — she can n't get it into her head that I 'm grown up .

sp.speaker: HARRY
sp.p: To theWell , I 've had about enough of her .

sp.speaker: AMAH
sp.p: ] The police will be here in ten minutes and I shall give you in charge instead of the man you allowed to escape .

sp.speaker: AMAH
sp.p: You give me policeman ? I no have do wrong . What for you send me to prison ?

sp.speaker: HARRY
sp.p: I daresay you know what a Chinese prison is like better than I do . I do n't think it 'll be long before you find it worth while to tell the truth .

sp.speaker: DAISY
sp.p: With increasing nervousness .Oh , Harry , I do n't think you ought to do anything before you 've had time to think . After all , there 's absolutely no proof .

sp.speaker: HARRY
sp.p: Looking at her with perplexity .I do n't understand . What is the mystery ?

sp.speaker: DAISY
sp.p: There is no mystery . Only I can n't bear the idea that my old amah should go to prison . She 's been almost a mother to me for so many years .

div.stage: There is a pause . HARRY looks from DAISY to the AMAH .

sp.speaker: HARRY
sp.p: To the AMAH .Then get out of here before the police come .

sp.speaker: AMAH
sp.p: You talkee so quick . No can understand .

sp.speaker: HARRY
sp.p: Yes , you can . Unless you 're out of here in ten minutes I shall give you in charge ... Go while the going 's good .

sp.speaker: AMAH
sp.p: I think I go smoke pipe .

sp.speaker: HARRY
sp.p: No , you do n't , you get out quick or I 'll throw you out myself .

sp.speaker: AMAH
sp.p: You no throw me out and I no go to prison .

sp.speaker: HARRY
sp.p: We 'll soon see about that .

div.stage: He seizes her roughly and is about to run her out into the courtyard .

sp.speaker: DAISY
sp.p: No , do n't , Harry . She 's my mother .

sp.speaker: HARRY
sp.p: That !

div.stage: He is aghast . He releases the AMAH . He looks at her with horror . DAISY covers her face with her hands . The AMAH gives a little snigger .

sp.speaker: AMAH
sp.p: Yes , Daisy , my daughter . She no wanchee tell . I think she a little ashamed of her mother .

sp.speaker: HARRY
sp.p: My God !

sp.speaker: AMAH
sp.p: I velly pletty girl long time ago . Daisy 's father , he call me his little lotus flower , he call me his little peach-blossom . By and by I no velly pletty girl any more and Daisy 's father he call me you old witch . Witch , that 's what he call me . Witch . He call me , you old hag . You velly bad man , I say to him . You no Christian . You go to hell , he say . All right , I say , you baptize me .HARRY turns away , with dismay , and repulsion . The AMAH takes her pipe and lights it .END OF SCENE IV

div.head: SCENE V

stage.stage: The courtyard in the ANDERSONS ’ part of the temple .

At the back is the outer wall raised by two or three steps from the ground . From the top of the wall , projects a shallow roof of yellow tiles supported by wooden pillars painted red , shabby and rather weather-worn , and this roof is raised in the middle of the wall , where there is a huge wooden gateway . When this is opened the street is seen and on the other side of it a high , blank , white wall . The courtyard is paved with great flags . On each side of it are living rooms .

There is a long rattan chair ; a round table and a couple of armchairs . GEORGE is lying on the long chair , looking at an illustrated paper , and the AMAH is seated on the ground , smoking her water-pipe .

sp.speaker: GEORGE
sp.p: With a smile , putting down the paper .You 're not as chatty as usual this afternoon , amah .

sp.speaker: AMAH
sp.p: Suppose I got nothing to talk about I no talk .

sp.speaker: GEORGE
sp.p: You are an example to your sex , amah . Your price is above rubies .

sp.speaker: AMAH
sp.p: No likee rubies velly much . No can sell velly much money .

sp.speaker: GEORGE
sp.p: In point of fact I was n't thinking of giving you rubies , even reconstructed , but if I did I can n't think you 'd be so indelicate as to sell them .

sp.speaker: AMAH
sp.p: I no think you velly funny man .

sp.speaker: GEORGE
sp.p: I was afraid you did n't . Would you think it funny if I sat on my hat ?

sp.speaker: AMAH
sp.p: Yes , I laugh then . Hi , hi .

sp.speaker: GEORGE
sp.p: The inscrutable heart of China expands to the self-same joke that convulses a duchess in London and a financier in New York .

sp.speaker: AMAH
sp.p: You more better read the paper .

sp.speaker: GEORGE
sp.p: Where 's Missy ?

sp.speaker: AMAH
sp.p: I think she in her room . You wanchee ?

sp.speaker: GEORGE
sp.p: No .

sp.speaker: AMAH
sp.p: I think she come by and by .

sp.speaker: GEORGE
sp.p: Looking at his watch .Mr. Anderson ought to be back from the office soon .There is a loud knocking at the door .Hulloa , who 's that ?

div.stage: A SERVANT comes out of the house and going to the gateway withdraws the bolt .

sp.speaker: AMAH
sp.p: I think doctor come see you , maybe .

sp.speaker: GEORGE
sp.p: Oh no , he 's not coming to-day . He said he 'd look in to-morrow before I started .

div.stage: The AMAH gets up and looks at the doorway of which now the SERVANT has opened one side . HAROLD KNOX and his sister SYLVIA are seen .

sp.speaker: KNOX
sp.p: May we come in ?

sp.speaker: GEORGE
sp.p: Good man . Of course .

div.stage: They come towards GEORGE . SYLVIA is a very pretty , simple , healthy , and attractive girl . She is dressed in a light summer frock . There is in her gait and manner something so spring-like and fresh that it is a pleasure to look at her .

sp.speaker: KNOX
sp.p: I 've brought my young sister along with me .As GEORGE rises to his feet .Do n't get up . You need n't put on any frills for a chit like that .

sp.speaker: GEORGE
sp.p: Nonsense . I 'm perfectly well .Shaking hands with SYLVIA .How d'you do ? My name is Conway .

sp.speaker: KNOX
sp.p: I only omitted to inform her of that fact because she already knew it .

sp.speaker: SYLVIA
sp.p: Strangely enough that happens to be true . But I wish you 'd lie down again .

sp.speaker: GEORGE
sp.p: I 'm sick of lying down . The doctor says I 'm perfectly all right . I 'm going home to-morrow .

sp.speaker: KNOX
sp.p: Catching sight of the AMAH .Hulloa , sweetheart , I did n't see you . Sylvia , I want you to know the only woman I 've ever loved .

sp.speaker: GEORGE
sp.p: Smiling .This is Mrs. Anderson 's amah .

sp.speaker: SYLVIA
sp.p: With a little friendly nod .How do you do ?

sp.speaker: AMAH
sp.p: All in a breath .Velly well , thank you . How do you do ? Velly well , thank you ... You Mr. Knox sister ?

sp.speaker: SYLVIA
sp.p: Yes .

sp.speaker: AMAH
sp.p: You missionary lady ?

sp.speaker: SYLVIA
sp.p: No .

sp.speaker: AMAH
sp.p: What for you come China then ?

sp.speaker: SYLVIA
sp.p: I came to see my brother .

sp.speaker: AMAH
sp.p: How old are you ?

sp.speaker: KNOX
sp.p: Be truthful , Sylvia .

sp.speaker: SYLVIA
sp.p: I 'm twenty-two .

sp.speaker: AMAH
sp.p: How many children you got ?

sp.speaker: SYLVIA
sp.p: I 'm not married .

sp.speaker: AMAH
sp.p: What for you no married if you twenty-two ?

sp.speaker: SYLVIA
sp.p: It does need an explanation , does n't it ? The truth is that nobody 's asked me .

sp.speaker: KNOX
sp.p: What a lie !

sp.speaker: AMAH
sp.p: You come China catchee husband ?

sp.speaker: SYLVIA
sp.p: Certainly not .

sp.speaker: AMAH
sp.p: You Christian ?

sp.speaker: SYLVIA
sp.p: Not a very good one , I 'm afraid .

sp.speaker: AMAH
sp.p: Who baptized you ?

sp.speaker: SYLVIA
sp.p: Well , you know , it 's an awfully long time ago . I forget .

sp.speaker: KNOX
sp.p: She 's like me , amah , she 's a Presbyterian .

sp.speaker: AMAH
sp.p: You go to hell then . Only Seventh Day Adventists no go to hell .

sp.speaker: SYLVIA
sp.p: It 'll be rather crowded then , I 'm afraid .

sp.speaker: AMAH
sp.p: You only baptized once ?

sp.speaker: SYLVIA
sp.p: So far as I know .

sp.speaker: AMAH
sp.p: I baptized one , two , three , four , five times . I velly Christian woman .

sp.speaker: KNOX
sp.p: I say , old man , I do n't want to dash your fond hopes , but in point of fact we did n't come here to see you .

sp.speaker: GEORGE
sp.p: Why not ? Surely Miss Knox must want to see the principal sights of Peking .

sp.speaker: KNOX
sp.p: The man is not a raving lunatic , Sylvia . His only delusion is that he 's a humourist ... Sylvia thought she 'd like to call on Mrs. Harry .

sp.speaker: GEORGE
sp.p: I 'm sure Daisy will be very glad . Amah , go and tell Missy that there 's a lady .

sp.speaker: AMAH
sp.p: Can do .

div.stage: Exit .

sp.speaker: KNOX
sp.p: I say , have they caught any of those blighters who tried to kill you ?

sp.speaker: GEORGE
sp.p: No , not a chance . They were n't after me , you know ; they were after Harry .

sp.speaker: KNOX
sp.p: Is there anyone who has a grudge against him ?

sp.speaker: GEORGE
sp.p: I do n't think so . He does n't seem very keen on discussing the incident .

div.stage: DAISY comes in .

sp.speaker: KNOX
sp.p: Here she is . I 've brought my sister to see you , Mrs. Harry .

sp.speaker: DAISY
sp.p: Shaking hands .How do you do ?

sp.speaker: SYLVIA
sp.p: What a wonderful place you live in !

sp.speaker: DAISY
sp.p: It 's rather attractive , is n't it ? You must see the temple before you go .

sp.speaker: SYLVIA
sp.p: I 'd love to .

sp.speaker: DAISY
sp.p: Do sit down .To KNOX .What do you think of my patient ?

sp.speaker: KNOX
sp.p: I think he 's a fraud . I never saw anyone look so robust .

sp.speaker: DAISY
sp.p: Delighted .He 's made a wonderful recovery .

sp.speaker: GEORGE
sp.p: Thanks to you , Daisy . You can n't think how she nursed me .

sp.speaker: KNOX
sp.p: It was rather a narrow escape , was n't it ?

sp.speaker: DAISY
sp.p: For two days we thought he might die at any minute . It was — it was rather dreadful .

lg.l: And do you know , all that time she never left me a minute .
I do n't know how I can ever thank you .

sp.speaker: DAISY
sp.p: Oh , well , Harry had his work . I did n't think he ought to be robbed of his night 's rest for a worthless creature like you , and I hated the idea of a paid nurse looking after you .

sp.speaker: SYLVIA
sp.p: You must have been worn out at the end of it .

sp.speaker: DAISY
sp.p: No , I 'm as strong as a horse . And it was such a relief to me when the doctor said he was out of danger , I forgot I was tired .

sp.speaker: KNOX
sp.p: I do n't know why you bothered about him . There are such a lot of fellows who want his job and they all know they could do it much better than he can .

sp.speaker: GEORGE
sp.p: Everyone 's been so extraordinarily good to me . I had no idea there was so much kindness in the world .

sp.speaker: DAISY
sp.p: To SYLVIA , very pleasantly .Will you come and look at the temple now while they 're bringing tea ?

sp.speaker: SYLVIA
sp.p: Yes , I 'd like to very much .

sp.speaker: DAISY
sp.p: I think you 'll enjoy your tea more if you feel you 've done the sight .

sp.speaker: SYLVIA
sp.p: It 's all so new to me . Everything interests me . I 've fallen passionately in love with Peking .

div.stage: They wander off , talking gaily .

sp.speaker: GEORGE
sp.p: Harold , you 're a very nice boy .

sp.speaker: KNOX
sp.p: That 's what the girls tell me . But I do n't know why you should .

sp.speaker: GEORGE
sp.p: I think it was rather sporting of you to bring your sister to see Daisy .

sp.speaker: KNOX
sp.p: I do n't deserve any credit for that . She insisted on coming .

sp.speaker: GEORGE
sp.p: Oh ?

sp.speaker: KNOX
sp.p: She met Harry at the club and took rather a fancy to him . When I told her Daisy was a half-caste and people did n't bother much about her she got right up on her hind legs . I told her she 'd only just come out to China and did n't know what she was talking about and then she gave me what she called a bit of her mind . I was obliged to remark that if that was a bit I did n't much care about knowing the rest .

sp.speaker: GEORGE
sp.p: It sounds as though you 'd had a little tiff .

sp.speaker: KNOX
sp.p: She said she had no patience with the airs people gave themselves in the East . A Eurasian was just as good as anybody else . And when I happened to say I was coming here to-day to see how you were she said she 'd come too .

sp.speaker: GEORGE
sp.p: It 's very kind of her . Daisy leads a dreadfully lonely life . It would mean so much to her if she knew one or two white women . If they take to one another , you wo n't try to crab it , will you ? I fancy Daisy wants a friend rather badly .

sp.speaker: KNOX
sp.p: I should n't like it very much , you know . Would you much care for your sister to be very pally with a half-caste ?

sp.speaker: GEORGE
sp.p: Daisy is one in a thousand . You can n't think what she 's done for me during my illness . My mother could n't have taken more care of me .

sp.speaker: KNOX
sp.p: They 're often very good-hearted . But as a matter of fact nothing I can say will have the least effect on Sylvia . Girls have changed a lot since the war . If she wants to do a thing and she thinks it right , she 'll do it . And if I try to interfere she 's quite capable of telling me to go to the devil .

sp.speaker: GEORGE
sp.p: She seems to be a young woman of some character .

sp.speaker: KNOX
sp.p: Perhaps because she 's had rather a rough time . The fellow she was engaged to was killed in the war and she was awfully cut up . She drove an ambulance for the last two years and then she went up to Girton . After that my father thought she 'd better come out here for a bit .

sp.speaker: GEORGE
sp.p: She ought to like it .

sp.speaker: KNOX
sp.p: If she does n't put up people 's backs too much . She can n't stand anything like injustice or cruelty . If she thinks people are unkind to Daisy or sniffy about her , she 'll stick to her like a leech . However , I daresay she 'll get married .

sp.speaker: GEORGE
sp.p: Smiling .That 'll learn her .

sp.speaker: KNOX
sp.p: Why do n't you marry her ? It 's about time you settled down .

sp.speaker: GEORGE
sp.p: With a chuckle .You fool .

sp.speaker: KNOX
sp.p: Why ? You 're by way of being rather eligible , are n't you ?

sp.speaker: GEORGE
sp.p: I do n't know why you want to get rid of her . She seems a very nice sister .

sp.speaker: KNOX
sp.p: Of course I love having her with me , but she does cramp my style a bit . And she ought to marry . She 'd make you a first-rate wife .

sp.speaker: GEORGE
sp.p: Much too good for the likes of me .

sp.speaker: KNOX
sp.p: Of course she 's a bit independent , but one has to put up with that in girls nowadays . And she 's as good as gold .

sp.speaker: GEORGE
sp.p: One can see that at a mile , my son .

sp.speaker: KNOX
sp.p: I say , who was Rathbone , Daisy 's first husband , do you know ?

sp.speaker: GEORGE
sp.p: His face a blank .Harry told me he was an American . He said he was in business in the F. M. S .

sp.speaker: KNOX
sp.p: That 's what Harry told me . I met a fellow the other day who lives in Singapore who told me he 'd never heard of Rathbone .

sp.speaker: GEORGE
sp.p: Chaffing him .Perhaps he did n't move in the exalted circles that a friend of yours would naturally move in .

sp.speaker: KNOX
sp.p: I suppose there was a Mr. Rathbone ?

div.stage: There is a distant sound in the street of Chinese instruments being played .

sp.speaker: GEORGE
sp.p: Hulloa , there 's the procession coming along .

sp.speaker: KNOX
sp.p: What procession ?

sp.speaker: GEORGE
sp.p: It 's a Manchu wedding . The amah was talking about it this morning .

sp.speaker: KNOX
sp.p: I must call Sylvia . She 'd love to see it . Sylvia .

div.stage: DAISY and SYLVIA come out of the house just as he calls .

sp.speaker: SYLVIA
sp.p: Do n't shout , Harold .

sp.speaker: KNOX
sp.p: Come along and have your education improved . A Manchu wedding is just going to pass by ....

sp.speaker: SYLVIA
sp.p: Oh , good , let 's go out into the street !

sp.speaker: DAISY
sp.p: You can see it just as well from here . I 'll have the doors opened . Boy , open the gate .

sp.speaker: KNOX
sp.p: Yes , that 's the ticket . We shall see it better from here .

div.stage: WU during the last few speeches has appeared with the tea , which he sets down on the table . On receiving DAISY 'S order he goes to the doorway and draws the bolt . He pulls back one heavy door while KNOX pulls back the other . The empty street is seen . The music grows louder . Now the procession comes , gay , brilliant , and barbaric against the white wall of the street ; first men on horseback , then Buddhist monks in gray , with their shaven heads ; then the band , playing wild , discordant music ; after them passes a long string of retainers in red , with strange shaped hats ; then come retainers bearing in open palanquins great masses of cardboard fruits and all manner of foodstuffs , silver vessels and gold ; these are followed by two or three youths on horseback , gorgeously dressed , and these again by the palanquin , carved and richly painted and gilt , of the bride . Then pass more priests and another band and finally a last string of retainers in red . When the last one has disappeared a beggar shows himself at the open doorway . He is excessively thin , and he has a bush of long , bristly hair ; he is clothed in pale rags , torn and patched ; his legs and feet are bare . He puts out a bony hand and breaks into a long , high-pitched whine .

sp.speaker: KNOX
sp.p: Oh , Lord , get out !

sp.speaker: DAISY
sp.p: Oh , no , please , Harold , give him a copper or two .

sp.speaker: GEORGE
sp.p: Daisy never lets a beggar go away without something .

sp.speaker: DAISY
sp.p: It 's not because I 'm charitable . I 'm afraid they 'll bring me bad luck .

sp.speaker: KNOX
sp.p: Taking a coin from his pocket .Here you are , Clarence . Now buzz off .

div.stage: The beggar takes his dole and saunters away . WU closes the doors .

sp.speaker: SYLVIA
sp.p: Enthusiastically .I am glad I saw that .

sp.speaker: DAISY
sp.p: You 'll get very tired of that sort of thing before you 've been here long . Now let 's have tea .

sp.speaker: SYLVIA
sp.p: Oh , I do n't think we 'll stay , thank you very much . We have another call to make .

sp.speaker: DAISY
sp.p: How tiresome of you . Harry ought to be back in a few minutes . He 'll be disappointed not to have seen you .

sp.speaker: SYLVIA
sp.p: I promised to go and see Mrs. Stopfort . Do you know her ?

sp.speaker: DAISY
sp.p: I know who you mean .

sp.speaker: SYLVIA
sp.p: I think people are being absolutely beastly to her . It simply makes my blood boil .

sp.speaker: DAISY
sp.p: Oh , how ?

sp.speaker: SYLVIA
sp.p: Well , you know that her husband 's a drunken brute who 's treated her abominably for years . At last she fell in love with a man and now her husband is going to divorce her . It 's monstrous that he should be able to .

sp.speaker: DAISY
sp.p: Are the ladies of Peking giving her the cold shoulder ?

sp.speaker: KNOX
sp.p: The cold shoulder hardly describes it . The frozen silverside .

sp.speaker: GEORGE
sp.p: I think she 's well rid of Reggie Stopfort at any price , but I 'm sorry the other party is Andre Leroux .

sp.speaker: SYLVIA
sp.p: Why ? She introduced me to him . I thought he was a very nice fellow .

sp.speaker: GEORGE
sp.p: Well , you see , if he 'd been English or American , he would have married her as a matter of course .

sp.speaker: SYLVIA
sp.p: So I should hope .

sp.speaker: DAISY
sp.p: Because she was divorced on his account , you mean ?

sp.speaker: GEORGE
sp.p: Yes . But the French have n't our feeling on that matter . I 'm not quite sure if Andre will be willing to marry her .

sp.speaker: SYLVIA
sp.p: Oh , that would be dreadful ! Under those circumstances the man must marry the woman . He simply must .

sp.speaker: GEORGE
sp.p: Of course .

sp.speaker: KNOX
sp.p: Come along , Sylvia . We wo n't discuss women 's rights now .

sp.speaker: SYLVIA
sp.p: Giving DAISY her hand very cordially .And if there 's anything I hate it 's people who say they 're going and then do n't go . Good-bye , Mrs. Anderson .

sp.speaker: DAISY
sp.p: It 's been very nice to see you .

sp.speaker: SYLVIA
sp.p: I do hope you 'll come and see me soon . I 'm so very much alone you 'd be doing me a charity if you 'd look me up . We might do the curio shops together .

sp.speaker: DAISY
sp.p: That would be great fun .

sp.speaker: SYLVIA
sp.p: Good-bye , Mr. Conway . I 'm glad to see you so well .

sp.speaker: GEORGE
sp.p: Thank you very much , good-bye .

div.stage: KNOX and SYLVIA go out . DAISY has walked with them towards the doorway and now returns to GEORGE .

sp.speaker: GEORGE
sp.p: What a very nice girl , Daisy .

sp.speaker: DAISY
sp.p: She seems to make a specialty of speckled peaches . First me and then Mrs. Stopfort .

sp.speaker: GEORGE
sp.p: I was hoping you 'd like her .

sp.speaker: DAISY
sp.p: It 's hardly probable . She 's everything that I 'm not . She has everything that I have n't . No , I do n't like her . But I 'd give anything in the world to be her .

sp.speaker: GEORGE
sp.p: Smiling .I do n't think you need envy her .

sp.speaker: DAISY
sp.p: Do n't you think she 's pretty ?

sp.speaker: GEORGE
sp.p: Yes , very . But you 're so much more than pretty . I expect you have more brains in your little finger than she has in her whole body .

lg.l: She has something that I have n't got , George , and
I 'd give my soul to have .

sp.speaker: GEORGE
sp.p: Embarrassed .I do n't know what you mean .Changing the conversation abruptly .Daisy , now that I 'm going away ....

sp.speaker: DAISY
sp.p: Interrupting .Are you really going to-morrow ?

sp.speaker: GEORGE
sp.p: Breezily .I 'm quite well . I 'm ashamed to have stayed so long .

sp.speaker: DAISY
sp.p: I do n't look forward very much to the long , empty days when you 're no longer here .

sp.speaker: GEORGE
sp.p: Seriously .I must go , Daisy . I really must .

sp.speaker: DAISY
sp.p: After a moment 's pause .What were you going to say to me ? Do n't thank me for anything I may have done . It 's given me a happiness I never knew before .

lg.l: Except for you I should have died . And when I think of the past
I am ashamed .

sp.speaker: DAISY
sp.p: What does the past matter ? The past is dead and gone .

sp.speaker: GEORGE
sp.p: And I 'm ashamed when I think how patient you were when I was irritable , how kind and thoughtful . I hardly knew I wanted a thing before you gave it to me . Sometimes when I felt I could n't breathe , the tenderness of your hand on my forehead — oh , it was like a dip in a highland stream on a summer day . I think I never knew that there was in you the most precious thing that anyone can have , goodness . Oh , Daisy , it makes me feel so humble .

sp.speaker: DAISY
sp.p: Goodness ?With the shadow of a laugh .Oh , George .

sp.speaker: GEORGE
sp.p: It 's because Harry is better and simpler than I am that he was able to see it in you . He felt it in you always and he was right .

div.stage: The AMAH comes in .

sp.speaker: DAISY
sp.p: Sharply .What d'you want ?

div.stage: The AMAH crosses from one to the other and a thin smile crosses her eyes .

sp.speaker: AMAH
sp.p: Master telephone , Daisy .

sp.speaker: DAISY
sp.p: Why did n't you take the message ?

div.stage: She is about to go into the house .

sp.speaker: AMAH
sp.p: He have go now . He say very much hurry . I say no can findee you . I think you go out .

sp.speaker: DAISY
sp.p: Why did you say that ?

sp.speaker: AMAH
sp.p: I think more better , maybe .

sp.speaker: GEORGE
sp.p: Smiling .That 's right , amah . Never tell the truth when a lie will do as well .

sp.speaker: DAISY
sp.p: Well , what was the message ?

sp.speaker: AMAH
sp.p: Master say he must to go Tientsin . Very important business . No come back to-night . Come back first train to-morrow .

sp.speaker: DAISY
sp.p: Very well . Tell the boy that we shall be only two to dinner .

sp.speaker: AMAH
sp.p: I go talkee he .

div.stage: Exit .

sp.speaker: GEORGE
sp.p: Urbanely .I say , I do n't want to be an awful trouble to you . I think I 'd better go back to my own place to-night .

sp.speaker: DAISY
sp.p: Looking at him .Why should you do that ?

sp.speaker: GEORGE
sp.p: I was going to-morrow anyway .

sp.speaker: DAISY
sp.p: Do you think my reputation is such a sensitive flower ?

sp.speaker: GEORGE
sp.p: Lightly .Of course not . But people are n't very charitable . It seems rather funny I should stay here when Harry 's away .

sp.speaker: DAISY
sp.p: What do you suppose I care if people gossip ?

sp.speaker: GEORGE
sp.p: I care for you .

sp.speaker: DAISY
sp.p: With a smile , almost archly .It 's not very flattering to me that you should insist on going the moment Harry does . Do I bore you so much as all that ?

sp.speaker: GEORGE
sp.p: With a chuckle .How can you talk such nonsense ? I have n't wanted to get well too quickly . I 've so enjoyed sitting quietly here while you read or sewed . I 've got so much in the habit of seeing you about me that if I do n't go at once I shall never be able to bring myself to go at all .

sp.speaker: DAISY
sp.p: Since that horrible accident I 've been rather nervous at the thought of sleeping here by myself . I 'm terrified at the thought of being left alone to-night .

sp.speaker: GEORGE
sp.p: Come in with me , then . The Knoxes will be delighted to put you up for the night .

lg.stage: With a sudden change of manner .
lg.l: I do n't want you to go ,
George . I want you to stay .

sp.speaker: GEORGE
sp.p: As serious as she is .Daisy , do n't be too hard on me . You do n't know . You do n't know .With an effort he regains his self-control and returns to his easy , chaffing tone .Do n't forget it 's not only a wound in the lung that I 've been suffering from . While you and the doctor between you have been patching that up , I 've been busy sticking together the pieces of a broken heart . It 's nicely set now , no one could tell that there 'd ever been anything wrong with it , but I do n't think it would be very wise to give it a sudden jolt or jerk .

sp.speaker: DAISY
sp.p: In a low quivering voice .Why do you say things like that ? What is the good of making pretences ?

sp.speaker: GEORGE
sp.p: Determined to keep the note of lightness .It was very silly of me to bother you with my little troubles . It was very hot . I was overworked and nervous at the time or I should n't have made so much of it . I 'm sure that you 'll be as pleased as I am to know that I 'm making a very good recovery , thank you .

sp.speaker: DAISY
sp.p: As though asking a casual question .You do n't care for me any more ?

sp.speaker: GEORGE
sp.p: I have the greatest affection for you . I admire you and of course I 'm grateful to you . But if I thought I was in love with you I was mistaken .

sp.speaker: DAISY
sp.p: Do you know why I would n't have a professional nurse and when you were unconscious for two days refused to leave you for a minute ? Do you know why , afterwards , at night when you grew delirious I would n't let Harry watch you ? I said it would interfere with his work . I dared not leave you for a single moment . And it was your secret and mine . I would n't let anybody in the world share it with me . Do you know what you said in your delirium ?

sp.speaker: GEORGE
sp.p: Disturbed .I expect I talked an awful lot of rot . People always do , I believe .

sp.speaker: DAISY
sp.p: Passionately .You used to call me , “ Daisy , Daisy , ” as though your heart was breaking . And when I leaned over you and said : “ I 'm here , ” you would take my face in your hands so that I could hardly believe you were n't conscious . And you said : “ I love you . ”

sp.speaker: GEORGE
sp.p: Oh , God !

sp.speaker: DAISY
sp.p: And sometimes I did n't know how to calm you . You were frantic because you thought they were taking me away from you . “ I can n't bear it , ” you said , “ I shall die . ” I had to put my hands over your mouth so that no one should hear .

sp.speaker: GEORGE
sp.p: I did n't know what I was saying . I was n't myself . It was just the madness of the fever .

sp.speaker: DAISY
sp.p: And sometimes you were so exquisitely tender . Your voice was soft and caressing . And you called me by sweet names so that the tears ran down my cheeks . You thought you held me in your arms and you pressed me to your heart . You were happy then ; you were so happy that I was afraid you 'd die of it . I know what love is and you love me .

sp.speaker: GEORGE
sp.p: For God 's sake , stop . Why do you torture me ?

sp.speaker: DAISY
sp.p: And then you were madly jealous . You hated Harry . I think you could have killed him .

sp.speaker: GEORGE
sp.p: That 's not true . That 's infamous . Never . Never .

sp.speaker: DAISY
sp.p: Oh , you can say that with your lips ! Sometimes you thought he put his arms round me and kissed me and you sobbed aloud . Oh , it was so painful . I forgot that you were unconscious and I took your hands and said : “ He 's not here . You and I are alone , alone , alone . ” And sometimes I think you understood . You fell back . And a look of peace came on your face as if you were in heaven and you said — do you know what you said ? You said : “ Beloved , beloved , beloved . ”

div.stage: Her voice breaks and the tears course down her cheeks . GEORGE is shattered by what she has told him .

sp.speaker: GEORGE
sp.p: I suppose there are few of us that would n't turn away from ourselves in horror if the innermost thoughts of our heart , the thoughts we 're only conscious of to hate , were laid bare . But that shameful thing that showed itself in me is n't me . I disown it ....

sp.speaker: DAISY
sp.p: I thought you had more courage . I thought you had more sense . Do you call that you , a few conventional prejudices ? The real you is the love that consumes you more hotly than ever the fever did . The only you is the you that loves me . The rest is only frills . It 's a domino that you put on at a masked ball .

sp.speaker: GEORGE
sp.p: You do n't know what you say . Frills ? It 's honour , and duty , and decency . It 's everything that makes it possible for me to cling to the shadow of my self-respect .

sp.speaker: DAISY
sp.p: Oh , all that means nothing . You fool . You might as well try with your bare hands to stop the flow of the Yangtze .

sp.speaker: GEORGE
sp.p: If I perish I perish . Oh , of course I love you . All night I 'm tortured with love and tortured with jealousy , but the day does come at last and then I can get hold of myself again . My love is some horrible thing gnawing at my heart-strings . I hate it and despise it . But I can fight it , fight it all the time . Oh , I 've been here too long . I ought to have got back to work long ago . Work is my only chance . Daisy , I beseech you to let me go .

sp.speaker: DAISY
sp.p: How can I let you go ? I love you .

sp.speaker: GEORGE
sp.p: Thunderstruck .You ?Impatiently , with a shrug of the shoulders .Oh , you 're talking nonsense .

sp.speaker: DAISY
sp.p: Why do you suppose I 've said all these things ? Do you think a woman cares twopence for a man 's love when she does n't love him ?

sp.speaker: GEORGE
sp.p: Oh , it 's impossible . You do n't know what you 're saying . I know how good and kind you are . You 've been touched by my love . You mistake pity for love .

sp.speaker: DAISY
sp.p: I 'm not good and I 'm not kind . There 's no room in my soul for pity . In my soul there 's only a raging hunger . If I know what you feel it 's because I feel it too . I love you , I love you , I love you .

sp.speaker: GEORGE
sp.p: And Harry ?

sp.speaker: DAISY
sp.p: What do I care about Harry ? I hate him because he 's stood between me and you .

sp.speaker: GEORGE
sp.p: He is your husband . He is my friend .

sp.speaker: DAISY
sp.p: He does n't exist . I 've loved you always from the first day I saw you . The others were nothing to me , Lee Tai and Harry and the rest . I 've loved you always . I 've never loved anyone but you . All these years I 've kept the letters you wrote to me . I 've read them till I know every word by heart . They 're all blurred and smudged with the tears I 've wept over them . They were all I had . Do you think I 'm going to let you go now ? All my pain , all my anguish , are nothing any more . I love you and you love me .

sp.speaker: GEORGE
sp.p: Oh , do n't , do n't !

sp.speaker: DAISY
sp.p: You can n't leave me now . If you leave me I shall kill myself .

sp.speaker: GEORGE
sp.p: I must go away . I must never see you again . Whatever happens we must never meet .

sp.speaker: DAISY
sp.p: Exasperated and impatient .That 's impossible . What will you say to Harry ?

sp.speaker: GEORGE
sp.p: If need be I 'll tell him the truth .

sp.speaker: DAISY
sp.p: What difference will that make ? Will you love me any the less ? Yes , tell him . Tell him that I love you and you only and that I belong to you and to you only .

sp.speaker: GEORGE
sp.p: Oh , Daisy , for God 's sake try and control yourself . We must do our duty , we must , we must .

sp.speaker: DAISY
sp.p: I know no duty . I only know love . There 's no room in my soul for anything else . You say that love is like a wild beast gnawing at your entrails . My love is a liberator . It 's freed me from a hateful past . It 's freed me from Harry . There 's nothing in the world now but you and me and the love that joins us . I want you , I want you .

sp.speaker: GEORGE
sp.p: Do n't , do n't ! Oh , this is madness ! There 's only one thing to be done . God , give me strength . Daisy , you know I love you . I love you with all my heart and soul . But it 's good-bye . I 'll never see you again . Never . Never . So help me God .

sp.speaker: DAISY
sp.p: How can you be so cruel ? You 're heartless . I 've wanted you all these years . I 've hungered for you . You do n't know what my humiliation has been . Pity me because I loved you . If you leave me now I shall die . You open the doors of heaven to me and then you slam them in my face . Have n't you made me unhappy enough ? You 'd have done better to kill me ten years ago . You trampled me in the mud and then you left me . Oh , what shall I do ?She sinks down to the ground , weeping as though her heart would break . GEORGE looks at her for a minute , his face distorted with agony ; he clenches his hands in the violence of his effort to control himself . He takes his hat and walks slowly towards the gate . He withdraws the bolt that holds it . When DAISY hears the sound of this she starts to her feet and staggers towards him .George . No , no . Not yet .

div.stage: She staggers and with a cry falls headlong . She has fainted .

sp.speaker: GEORGE
sp.p: Rushing towards her .Daisy . Daisy .He kneels down and takes her head in his hands . He is fearfully agitated .Oh , my darling , what is it ? Oh , my God ! Daisy ! Speak to me .Calling .Amah , amah !DAISY slowly opens her eyes .Oh , my beloved ! I thought you were dead .

sp.speaker: DAISY
sp.p: Lift me up .

sp.speaker: GEORGE
sp.p: You can n't stand .

div.stage: He raises her to her feet so that when she is erect she is in his arms . She puts her arms round his neck .

sp.speaker: DAISY
sp.p: Do n't leave me .

sp.speaker: GEORGE
sp.p: My precious . My beloved .

div.stage: She turns her face to him , offering her lips , and he bends his head and kisses her . She closes her eyes in ecstasy .

sp.speaker: DAISY
sp.p: Take me in . I feel so ill .

sp.speaker: GEORGE
sp.p: I 'll carry you .

div.stage: He lifts her up and carries her into the house . From the opposite side the AMAH appears . She goes to the gateway and slips the bolt forward into position . Then she comes to the tea-table , sits down and takes a scone .

sp.speaker: AMAH
sp.p: Hi , hi .She bites the scone and chews placidly . On her face is a smirk of irony .END OF SCENE V

div.head: SCENE VI

stage.stage: A small room in a Chinese house in Peking .

The walls are whitewashed , but the whitewash is not a little stained . Three or four scrolls hang on them , written over in large characters with inscriptions . On the floor is matting . The only furniture consists of a table , with a couple of chairs , a wooden pallet covered with matting , with cushions at one end of it , and a Korean chest heavily ornamented with brass . At the back are two windows , elaborately latticed and covered with rice paper , and a lightly carved door .

DAISY is seated in one of the chairs . She has taken her pocket mirror out of her bag and is looking at herself . She is gay and happy . The AMAH comes in . She carries a long-necked vase in which are a couple of carnations .

sp.speaker: AMAH
sp.p: I bring you flowers make room look pletty .

sp.speaker: DAISY
sp.p: Oh , you nice old thing ! Put them on the table .

sp.speaker: AMAH
sp.p: You look at yourself in looking-glass ?

sp.speaker: DAISY
sp.p: I 'm looking young . It suits me to be happy .

sp.speaker: AMAH
sp.p: You very pletty girl . I very pletty girl long time ago . You look alla same me some day .

sp.speaker: DAISY
sp.p: Amused .Heaven forbid .

sp.speaker: AMAH
sp.p: You velly good temper to-day , Daisy . You glad because George come .

sp.speaker: DAISY
sp.p: I did n't see him yesterday .

sp.speaker: AMAH
sp.p: He keep you waiting .

sp.speaker: DAISY
sp.p: The wretch . He always keeps me waiting . But what do I care as long as he comes ? We shall have three hours . Perhaps he 'll dine here . If he says he can , give him what he likes to eat . No one can make such delicious things as you can if you want to .

sp.speaker: AMAH
sp.p: You try flatter me .

sp.speaker: DAISY
sp.p: I do n't . You know very well you 're the best cook in China .

sp.speaker: AMAH
sp.p: Tickled .Oh , Daisy ! I know you more better than you think .

sp.speaker: DAISY
sp.p: You 're a wicked old woman .She gives her a kiss on both cheeks .What are they making such a row about next door ?

sp.speaker: AMAH
sp.p: Coolie , he got killed this morning . He have two small children . Their mother , she die long time ago .

sp.speaker: DAISY
sp.p: How dreadful ! Poor little things .

sp.speaker: AMAH
sp.p: You like see them . They here .

div.stage: She goes to the door and beckons . A little , old , shabby Chinaman comes in with two tiny children , a boy and a girl , one holding on to each hand . They are very solemn and shy and silent .

sp.speaker: DAISY
sp.p: Oh , what lambs !

sp.speaker: AMAH
sp.p: They no got money . This old man he say he take them and he bring them up . But he only coolie . He no got much money himself .

sp.speaker: DAISY
sp.p: Is he related to them ?

sp.speaker: AMAH
sp.p: No , him just velly good man . He no can do velly much . He just do what he can . The neighbours , they help little .

sp.speaker: DAISY
sp.p: But I 'll help too . Have you got any money on you ?

sp.speaker: AMAH
sp.p: I got two , three dollars .

sp.speaker: DAISY
sp.p: What 's the good of that ? Let him have this .

div.stage: She has a chain of gold beads round her neck . She takes it off and puts it in the old man 's hands .

sp.speaker: AMAH
sp.p: That chain very ispensive , Daisy .

sp.speaker: DAISY
sp.p: What do I care ? Let him sell it for what it 'll fetch . It 'll bring me luck .To the old man .You sabe ?

div.stage: He nods , smiling .

sp.speaker: AMAH
sp.p: I think he understand all right .

sp.speaker: DAISY
sp.p: Looking at the children .Are n't they sweet ? And so solemn .To the AMAH .You go chop-chop to the toy shop opposite and buy them some toys .

sp.speaker: AMAH
sp.p: Can do .

div.stage: She goes out . DAISY takes the children and sets them up on the table .

sp.speaker: DAISY
sp.p: Charmingly .Now you come and talk to me . Sit very still now or you 'll fall off .To the little boy .I wonder how old you are .To the old man .Wu ? Liu ?

sp.speaker: OLD MAN
sp.p: Liu .

sp.speaker: DAISY
sp.p: To the little boy .Six years old . Good gracious , you 're quite a man . If I had a little boy he 'd be older than you now . If I had a little boy I 'd dress him in such smart things . And I 'd bath him myself . I would n't let any horrid old amah bath him . And I would n't stuff him up with sweets like the Chinese do ; I 'd give him one piece of chocolate when he was a good boy . Gracious me , I 've got some chocolates here . Wait there . Sit quite still .She goes over to the shelf on which is a bag of chocolates .There 's one for you and one for you andto the old manone for you . And here 's one for me .

div.stage: The children and the Chinaman eat the chocolates solemnly . The AMAH returns with a doll and a child 's Peking cart .

sp.speaker: AMAH
sp.p: Have catchee toys .

sp.speaker: DAISY
sp.p: Look what kind old amah has brought you .She lifts the children off the table and gives the doll to the little girl and the cart to the boy .Here 's a beautiful doll for you and here 's a real cart for you .She sits down on the floor .Look , the wheels go round and everything .

sp.speaker: AMAH
sp.p: Have got more presents .

div.stage: She takes out of her sleeve little bladders with mouthpiece attached so that they can be blown up .

sp.speaker: DAISY
sp.p: What on earth is this ? Oh , I love them ! We must all have one .She distributes them and they all blow them up . There it the sound of scratching at the door .Who 's that , I wonder ?

sp.speaker: AMAH
sp.p: If you say come in , perhaps you see .

sp.speaker: DAISY
sp.p: Open the door , you old silly .She begins to blow up the balloon again . The AMAH goes to the door and opens it . LEE TAI steps in .Lee Tai . Send these away .The AMAH makes a sign to the old Chinaman , he gives each child a hand and with their presents they go out . The AMAH slips out after them .I thought you were dead .

sp.speaker: LEE TAI
sp.p: I 'm very much alive , thank you .

sp.speaker: DAISY
sp.p: Ah , well , we 'll hope for the best .

sp.speaker: LEE TAI
sp.p: I trust you 're not displeased to see me .

sp.speaker: DAISY
sp.p: Gaily .If you 'd come yesterday I should certainly have smacked your face , but to-day I 'm in such a good humour that even the sight of you is tolerable .

sp.speaker: LEE TAI
sp.p: You were n't here yesterday .

div.stage: The AMAH comes in carrying on a little wooden tray , two Chinese bowls and a tea-pot .

sp.speaker: DAISY
sp.p: My dear Mamma seems to think you 've come to pay me a visit . You must n't let me keep you too long .

sp.speaker: LEE TAI
sp.p: You are expecting someone ? I know .

div.stage: The AMAH goes out .

sp.speaker: DAISY
sp.p: Chaffing him .I always said you had a brain .

sp.speaker: LEE TAI
sp.p: No better a one than yours , Daisy . It was a clever trick when you got me to try to put your husband out of the way so that you should be free for George Conway .

sp.speaker: DAISY
sp.p: It was nothing to do with me . I told you I 'd have nothing to do with it . You made a hash of it . One can forgive the good for being stupid , but when rascals are fools there 's no excuse .

lg.l: The best laid schemes of mice and men , as my favourite poet
Robert Burns so elegantly puts it , gang aft agley .

sp.speaker: DAISY
sp.p: I do n't care a damn about your favourite poet . What have you come here for to-day ?

sp.speaker: LEE TAI
sp.p: As it turns out I do not see that there is any cause for regret that George Conway got the knife thrust that was intended for your husband . I wish it had gone a little deeper .

sp.speaker: DAISY
sp.p: Coolly .As it turns out you only did me a service . But still you have n't told me to what I owe the honour of your visit .

sp.speaker: LEE TAI
sp.p: Civility . I like to be on friendly terms with my tenants .

sp.speaker: DAISY
sp.p: Surprised .Your what ?

sp.speaker: LEE TAI
sp.p: Urbanely .This happens to be my house . When I discovered that your honourable mother had taken the rooms in this courtyard so that you might have a place where George Conway and you could safely meet I thought I would buy the whole house .

sp.speaker: DAISY
sp.p: I hope it was a good investment .

sp.speaker: LEE TAI
sp.p: Otherwise perhaps I should have hesitated . It was clever of you to find so convenient a place . With a curio shop in front into which anyone can be seen going without remark and an ill-lit passage leading to this court , it is perfect .

sp.speaker: DAISY
sp.p: What is the idea ?

sp.speaker: LEE TAI
sp.p: With a twinkle in his eyes .Are you a little frightened ?

sp.speaker: DAISY
sp.p: Not a bit . What can you do ? You can tell Harry . Tell him .

sp.speaker: LEE TAI
sp.p: Affably .George Conway would be ruined .

sp.speaker: DAISY
sp.p: With a shrug .He 'd lose his job . Perhaps you would give him another . You 're mixed up in so many concerns you could surely find use for a white man who speaks Chinese as well as George does .

sp.speaker: LEE TAI
sp.p: I find even your shamelessness attractive .

sp.speaker: DAISY
sp.p: I 'm profoundly grateful for the compliment .

sp.speaker: LEE TAI
sp.p: But do not fear . I shall do nothing . I bought this house because I like you to know that always , always you are in my hand . Where you go , I go . Where you are , I am . Sometimes you do not see me , but nevertheless I am close . I do nothing . I am content to wait .

sp.speaker: DAISY
sp.p: Your time is your own . I have no objection to your wasting it .

sp.speaker: LEE TAI
sp.p: One day , and I think that day is not very far distant , you will come to me . I was the first and I shall be the last . If you like I will marry you .

sp.speaker: DAISY
sp.p: With a smile .I thought you had two , if not three , wives already . I fancy that number four would have rather a thin time .

sp.speaker: LEE TAI
sp.p: My wife can be divorced . I am willing to marry you before the British Consul . We will go to Penang . I have a house there . You shall have motor cars .

sp.speaker: DAISY
sp.p: It 's astonishing how easy it is to resist temptations that do n't tempt you .

sp.speaker: LEE TAI
sp.p: Sneer . What do I care ? I wait .... What have you to do with white men ? You are not a white woman . What power has this blood of your father 's when it is mingled with the tumultuous stream which you have inherited through your mother from innumerable generations ? Our race is very pure and very strong . Strange nations have overrun us , but in a little while we have absorbed them so that no trace of a foreign people is left in us . China is like the Yangtze , which is fed by five hundred streams and yet remains unchanged , the river of golden sand , majestic , turbulent , indifferent , and everlasting . What power have you to swim against that mighty current ? You can wear European clothes and eat European food , but in your heart you are a Chinawoman . Are your passions the weak and vacillating passions of the white man ? There is in your heart a simplicity which the white man can never fathom and a deviousness which he can never understand . Your soul is like a rice patch cleared in the middle of the jungle . All around the jungle hovers , watchful and jealous , and it is only by ceaseless labour that you can prevent its inroads . One day your labour will be vain and the jungle will take back its own . China is closing in on you .

sp.speaker: DAISY
sp.p: My poor Lee Tai , you 're talking perfect nonsense .

sp.speaker: LEE TAI
sp.p: You 're restless and unhappy and dissatisfied because you 're struggling against instincts which were implanted in your breast when the white man was a hungry , naked savage . One day you will surrender . You will cast off the white woman like an outworn garment . You will come back to China as a tired child comes back to his mother . And in the immemorial usages of our great race you will find peace .

div.stage: There is a moment 's silence . DAISY passes her hand over her forehead . Against her will she is strangely impressed by what LEE TAI has said . She gives a little shudder and recovers herself .

sp.speaker: DAISY
sp.p: George Conway loves me , and I — Oh !

sp.speaker: LEE TAI
sp.p: The white man 's love lasts no longer than a summer day . It is a red , red rose . Now it flaunts its scented beauty proudly in the sun and to-morrow its petals , wrinkled and stinking , lie scattered on the ground .

div.stage: There is a sound of a footstep in the courtyard outside .

sp.speaker: DAISY
sp.p: Here he is . Go quickly .

div.stage: GEORGE opens the door and stops as he catches sight of LEE TAI .

sp.speaker: GEORGE
sp.p: Hulloa , who 's this ?

div.stage: LEE TAI steps forward , smiling and obsequious .

sp.speaker: LEE TAI
sp.p: I am the owner of this house . The amah complained that the roof leaked and I came to see for myself .

sp.speaker: GEORGE
sp.p: Frowning .It 's of no consequence . Please do n't bother about it .

sp.speaker: LEE TAI
sp.p: I wish I need n't . The amah has a virulent and active tongue — I am afraid she will give me no peace till I have satisfied her outrageous demands .

sp.speaker: GEORGE
sp.p: You speak extraordinarily good English .

sp.speaker: LEE TAI
sp.p: I am a graduate of the University of Edinburgh .

sp.speaker: DAISY
sp.p: Robert Burns is his favourite poet .

sp.speaker: LEE TAI
sp.p: I spent a year at Oxford and another at Harvard . I can express myself in English not without fluency .

sp.speaker: GEORGE
sp.p: Let me compliment you on your good sense in retaining your national costume . I think it a pity that the returned students should insist on wearing ugly tweed suits and billycock hats .

sp.speaker: LEE TAI
sp.p: I spent eight years abroad . I brought back with me no more admiration for Western dress than for Western civilization .

sp.speaker: GEORGE
sp.p: That is very interesting .

sp.speaker: LEE TAI
sp.p: You are pleased to be sarcastic .

sp.speaker: GEORGE
sp.p: And you , I think , are somewhat supercilious . Believe me , the time has passed when the mandarins of your country , in their impenetrable self-conceit , could put up a barrier against the advance of civilization . If you have any love for China you must see that her only chance to take her rightful place in the world is to accept honestly and sincerely the teaching of the West .

sp.speaker: LEE TAI
sp.p: And if in our hearts we despise and detest what you have to teach us ? For what reason are you so confident that you are so superior to us that it behooves us to sit humbly at your feet ? Have you excelled us in arts or letters ? Have our thinkers been less profound than yours ? Has our civilization been less elaborate , less complicated , less refined than yours ? Why , when you lived in caves and clothed yourselves with skins we were a cultured people . Do you know that we tried an experiment which is unique in the world ?

sp.speaker: GEORGE
sp.p: Good-naturedly .What experiment is that ?

sp.speaker: LEE TAI
sp.p: We sought to rule this great people not by force , but by wisdom . And for centuries we succeeded . Then why does the white man despise the yellow ? Shall I tell you ?

sp.speaker: GEORGE
sp.p: Do .

sp.speaker: LEE TAI
sp.p: With a smiling contempt .Because he has invented the machine-gun . That is your superiority . We are a defenceless horde and you can blow us into eternity .With a tinge of sadness .You have shattered the dream of our philosophers that the world could be governed by the power of law and order .... And now you are teaching our young men your secret . You have thrust your hideous inventions upon us . Fools . Do you not know that we have a genius for mechanics ? Do you not know that there are in this country four hundred millions of the most practical and industrious people in the world ? Do you think it will take us long to learn ? And what will become of your superiority when the yellow man can make as good guns as the white and fire them as straight ? You have appealed to the machine-gun and by the machine-gun shall you be judged .

div.stage: There is a pause . Suddenly GEORGE gives LEE TAI a scrutinizing glance .

sp.speaker: GEORGE
sp.p: What is your name ?

sp.speaker: LEE TAI
sp.p: With a thin , amused smile .Lee Tai Cheng .

sp.speaker: GEORGE
sp.p: With a frigid politeness .I 'm sure you are very busy , Mr. Lee . I wo n't detain you any longer .

sp.speaker: LEE TAI
sp.p: Still smiling .I wish you a good day .

div.stage: He bows slightly and shakes his own hands in the Chinese manner . He goes out . He leaves behind him an impression that is at once ironic and sinister .

sp.speaker: GEORGE
sp.p: What the devil is he doing here ?

sp.speaker: DAISY
sp.p: Amused .He came to make me an offer of marriage . I pointed out to him that I was married already .

sp.speaker: GEORGE
sp.p: Not without irritation .How did he know you were here ?

sp.speaker: DAISY
sp.p: He made it his business to find out .

sp.speaker: GEORGE
sp.p: Does he know that ...?

sp.speaker: DAISY
sp.p: Coolly .You know China better than most Englishmen . You know that the white man can do nothing without the Chinese knowing it . But they wo n't tell other white men unless — unless it 's to their advantage to do so .

sp.speaker: GEORGE
sp.p: You told me that this house belonged to the amah .

sp.speaker: DAISY
sp.p: Smiling .That was a slight exaggeration .

sp.speaker: GEORGE
sp.p: You put it very mildly .

sp.speaker: DAISY
sp.p: You said you would n't come to the temple . It meant finding some place where we could meet or never seeing you at all .

sp.speaker: GEORGE
sp.p: Sombrely .We began with deceit and with deceit we 've continued .

sp.speaker: DAISY
sp.p: Tenderly .There 's no deceit in my love , George . After all , our love is the only thing that matters .

sp.speaker: GEORGE
sp.p: With a certain awkwardness .I 'm afraid I 've kept you waiting . Andre Leroux came to see me just as I was leaving the Legation .

sp.speaker: DAISY
sp.p: Remembering .I know . Mrs. Stopfort 's young man .

sp.speaker: GEORGE
